border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/L7DEg5L2P0w\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 14:28:38 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f524cef7ed0ee001e25d804?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"440da988a23aa1803c963933e0f95284","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn56@2020_4/2020/09/04/16-37-57-440_aa581878b1eb5a8d.webp","destWidth":1579,"destHeight":1184,"sourceBytes":155476,"destBytes":155476,"author":"insider@insider.com (James Bosworth, Latin America Risk Report)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f524ac37ed0ee001e25d7e0?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn15@2020_3/2020/09/04/16-38-07-143_8fc0acde4d163300.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f5242ac7ed0ee001e25d79f?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn84@2020_4/2020/09/04/16-38-01-229_c78276a97ff60e3c.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f5242ac7ed0ee001e25d79e?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn68@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-37-59-336_8ead206fcad2466f.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f524aad7ed0ee001e25d7df?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn72@2020_5/2020/09/04/16-38-06-757_d0af3521d161a004.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ec55950f34d054e3b49bac9?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn59@2020_2/2020/09/04/16-37-56-786_50d952a75d0ffd92.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f524aa8e6ff30001d4e714b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn40@2020_4/2020/09/04/16-37-52-624_869a9c1897dffe49.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f524ab2e6ff30001d4e714d?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn84@2020_4/2020/09/04/16-38-16-428_fd19874bff82dfe0.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn3@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-38-03-978_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=L7DEg5L2P0w:Oa-VUeWtfVM:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn51@2020_5/2020/09/04/16-38-07-503_ba24aec656c8f1c4.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=L7DEg5L2P0w:Oa-VUeWtfVM:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn16@2020_2/2020/09/04/16-37-54-066_20ab696c0fca57c6.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn24@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-37-59-085_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=L7DEg5L2P0w:Oa-VUeWtfVM:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn84@2020_3/2020/09/04/16-38-00-393_ac20d9904ea83832.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/L7DEg5L2P0w":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn52@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-38-06-521_9bd2add5962042e4.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599237433642},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","title":"Voting in the 2020 presidential election officially starts today as North Carolina sends out over 600,000 mail ballots","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/2020-election-voting-begins-september-4-north-carolina-mails-ballots-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f5158d27ed0ee001e25d64c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Mail ballots\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Mike Babinski opens applications for voter ballots at the Cuyahoga County Board of Elections Tuesday, July 14, 2020, in Cleveland\n<p class=\"copyright\">AP Photo/Tony Dejak</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Voting in the 2020 presidential election officially starts on September 4 as North Carolina begins sending out mail ballots.</li>\n<li>The Tar Heel State, which allows all registered voters to cast votes by mail, is the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/when-will-i-get-november-absentee-mail-ballot-state-guide-2020-8\">first state in the nation</a> to start sending mail ballots 60 days before Election Day.&#160;</li>\n<li>Over 643,000 North Carolinians have already requested to vote by mail, a 16-fold increase over the number of North Carolina voters who requested a mail ballot by Sept. 4 in 2016.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The first ballots of the 2020 presidential election are being distributed in North Carolina today, kicking off the final sprint to the last day of in-person voting on Nov. 3.</p><p>North Carolina allows any registered voter to vote by mail, without them needing an excuse. Sixty days before Election Day, it is the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/when-will-i-get-november-absentee-mail-ballot-state-guide-2020-8\">first state in the nation</a> to start sending mail ballots to those who have already requested them, <a href=\"https://www.ncsl.org/research/elections-and-campaigns/vopp-table-7-when-states-mail-out-absentee-ballots.aspx\">according to the National Council of State Legislatures.&#160;</a></p><p>A total of 643,000 voters have requested ballots for the presidential election as of Friday, based on University of Florida professor Michael McDonald's <a href=\"https://electproject.github.io/Early-Vote-2020G/NC.html\">analysis of state data</a>. Already that figure represents a nearly four-fold increase over the total of 168,351 North Carolinians who voted by mail in the 2016 presidential election.</p><p>Mail ballot request rates already substantially outpace 2016 levels of mail voting, the election scholar found. So far, over 9% of North Carolina's approximately 7 million registered voters have requested a ballot. In 2016, 3.5% of North Carolinians who voted in the presidential election cast their ballots by mail, according to US Census data.&#160;</p><p>As of Sept. 3, the number of requests is 16 times higher than the approximately 37,000 North Carolinians who requested mail ballots by the same date in 2016, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/OldNorthStPol/status/1301483635237888003\">according to analysis</a> from Catawba College political science professor Michael Bitzer, who has been tracking North Carolina's ballot request data <a href=\"http://www.oldnorthstatepolitics.com/\">throughout the summer.</a></p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Michael McDonald  (@ElectProject) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1301860604794286081?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">September 4, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>There's also a stark partisan divide in the makeup of those who have requested their ballots so far. <a href=\"https://twitter.com/OldNorthStPol/status/1301485369083527170/photo/2\">Per McDonald's analysis</a>, 52% of the requests received as of Thursday came from registered Democrats, 31% from unaffiliated voters, and 16% from registered Republicans. At the same time in 2016, 37% of requests came from Democrats, 28% from unaffiliated voters, and 35% from Republicans.&#160;</p><p>This year, North Carolina, which accounts for 15 electoral college votes, <a href=\"https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/north-carolina-crucial-battleground-state-2020/story?id=72544898\">is a hotly-contested battleground in the presidential race</a> between President Donald Trump and Democratic nominee Joe Biden.</p><p>There's also <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/thom-tillis-vs-cal-cunningham-north-carolina-election-polls-fundraising-2020-7\">a highly competitive US Senate race</a> between first-term Republican Thom Tillis and Democrat Cal Cunningham, rated as a tossup by most major election forecasters; <a href=\"https://abcnews.go.com/Health/wireStory/nc-governors-race-sets-pace-democrats-south-72771623\">a gubernatorial election</a> between incumbent Democratic Gov. Roy Cooper and Lt. Gov Dan Forest; US House elections <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2019/12/03/north-carolinas-new-congressional-map-shifts-two-seats-toward-democrats/?arc404=true\">under the state's newly-drawn congressional map</a>; and several key legislative races that could decide control of both houses of the state legislature.&#160;</p><p>September 4 also marks the first day that voters in all 50 states will be able to request their mail ballot. Mississippi, the latest state to begin taking absentee ballot requests, <a href=\"https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/documents/elections/Step-by-Step%20Guide%20to%20Absentee%20Voting_forweb.pdf\">will also start accepting applications.</a></p><p>Several other states will follow North Carolina and begin sending out ballots starting<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/when-will-i-get-november-absentee-mail-ballot-state-guide-2020-8\">&#160;in mid-September</a> to those who have requested them. And some, including Michigan, Minnesota, Pennsylvania, and Virginia, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/when-is-early-voting-in-each-state-2020-8\">will start early in-person voting</a> as early as the week of Sept. 18. The first three hold a form of early voting called \"in-person absentee\" voting where a voter can cast a paper ballot at their local election office instead of at a traditional polling place.&#160;</p><p>Forty-five days before the election, or September 19 this year, marks the deadline for states to send absentee ballots to overseas and military voters covered under the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act.</p><p>At a Wednesday event in North Carolina, Trump, who has spent the last several months <a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2020/09/03/politics/election-threat-trump-mail-in-voting-claims-invs/index.html\">spreading misinformation</a> that mail voting is inherently fraudulent, <a href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2020-election/trump-encourages-north-carolina-residents-vote-twice-test-mail-system-n1239140\">suggested that voters should attempt to vote twice</a>, by mail and then in-person on Election Day to test whether the state's voting system can detect voter fraud.&#160;</p><p>It is a federal crime <a href=\"https://uscode.house.gov/view.xhtml?req=(title:52%20section:10307%20edition:prelim)\">to vote twice in a federal election</a>, and <a href=\"https://www.ncsl.org/research/elections-and-campaigns/double-voting.aspx\">most state laws also ban voting twice in state elections.</a></p><p>As the North Carolina State Board of Elections <a href=\"https://twitter.com/NCSBE/status/1301527393799213056\">pointed out in a Thursday statement</a>, <a href=\"https://www.ncsl.org/research/elections-and-campaigns/double-voting.aspx\">it is a Class I felony under North Carolina law</a> to vote twice in the same election, and state election officials employ a number of processes to prevent that type of fraud.&#160;</p><p>\"Electronic pollbooks with information about who has already voted are used at every early voting site. If a voter tries to check in who has already voted, they will be prevented from voting a regular ballot,\" Executive Director Karen Binson Bell said. \"A voter will be offered a provisional ballot if they insist on voting, and this ballot will be researched after Election Day to determine whether it should be counted.\"</p><p>In addition to pollbook systems used within states, election officials also share voter records with other states through programs like the Electronic Registration Information Center <a href=\"https://ericstates.org/\">(ERIC)</a> to maintain accurate and up-to-date voter rolls and identify potential instances of fraud, including people voting in multiple states in the same election.&#160;&#160;</p><p>The Heritage Foundation, a conservative think thank that maintains a <a href=\"https://www.heritage.org/voterfraud/search?combine=&state=All&year=&case_type=All&fraud_type=24503&page=0ype=24503&#38;page=0\">database of voter fraud cases</a>, has identified 118 criminal convictions or other official findings of duplicate voting between 2004 and 2020.&#160;</p><p>Brinson Bell emphasized that the Board of Elections \"strongly discourages\" voters from contributing to long lines at in-person polling locations by going to check in-person whether their mail-in vote has been counted. She instead encouraged voters to instead use North Carolina's online ballot tracking system, which is launching in the next few days, to verify that their ballot has been received.&#160;</p><bi-shortcode id=\"expanded-coverage\" class=\"mceNonEditable\" data-source=\"insider-voter-guide\" data-show-header=\"false\">Expanded Coverage Module: 00:37:13","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","title":"Insider Retail: Inside McDonald's whirlwind week of lawsuits and a collaboration, plus a look at how brands are using TikTok to win over customers","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/inside-mcdonalds-whirlwind-week-and-how-brands-are-using-tiktok-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4e6d0c7ed0ee001e25cb87?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Pumpkin spice donuts 5\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Irene compared Dunkin&#39; and Krispy Kreme&#39;s pumpkin spice donuts.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Irene Jiang/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Hello and happy Friday!</p><p>Welcome to another week of Insider Retail, Business Insider's weekly round-up of everything that's happening in restaurants and retail. If you haven't already subscribed, you can do so <a href=\"https://newsletter.businessinsider.com/click/19921095.876/aHR0cDovL25ld3NsZXR0ZXIuYnVzaW5lc3NpbnNpZGVyLmNvbS9qb2luLzRucC9kcml2ZXRocnU_bnJfZW1haWxfcmVmZXJlcj0xJnV0bV9zb3VyY2U9U2FpbHRocnUmdXRtX21lZGl1bT1lbWFpbCZ1dG1fY29udGVudD1Ecml2ZVRocnU/5c818d302ddf9c27c19a8b1aB1c4ef4a7\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\">here</a> and enjoy an immediate boost to your Fridays, brought to you by me, Shoshy Ciment, and my colleague, Kate Taylor.</p><p>Now let's get to the news:</p><h2><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/inside-mcdonalds-black-franchisees-quest-for-equality-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">McDonald's: A discrimination lawsuit, a Travis Scott Collab, and more concerns at the top</a></h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f523e507ed0ee001e25d78e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"travis scott mcdonald&#39;s\" height=\"1875\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">McDonald&#39;s</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>A lot happened in the McDonald's universe this week. Here's everything in a nutshell.</p><ul><li>We learned a bit more about <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/david-fairhust-former-head-of-hr-at-mcdonalds-under-scrutiny-2020-8\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">David Fairhust</a>, the former McDonald's HR head who was reportedly fired for making women uncomfortable. Some insiders described his behavior as <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mcdonalds-fired-head-of-hr-faces-renewed-scrutiny-2020-8\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">\"gross and dirty.\"</a> This all comes as the chain sues its former CEO Steve Easterbrook.</li><li>McDonald's was also hit with a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/black-ex-franchisees-sue-mcdonalds-in-racial-discrimination-case-2020-8\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">$1 billion racial-discrimination lawsuit</a>, filed by 52 Black ex-franchisees. Read more about the lawsuit, which has been a long time coming, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/inside-mcdonalds-black-franchisees-quest-for-equality-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">here</a>.</li><li>Amid the tension, the chain launched a collaboration with rapper <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/the-inside-story-of-mcdonalds-travis-scott-collaboration-2020-8\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Travis Scott,</a> which includes adding a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mcdonalds-partners-with-travis-scott-in-cactus-jack-deal-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">special meal</a> to its menu.</li></ul><p>Needless to say, it's been a busy week for the fast-food chain. And for Kate, who covers it.&#160;</p><h2><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/power-list-top-brands-on-tiktok-include-chipotle-nike-crocs-2020-8\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">The brands are getting in on TikTok</a></h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f46c686db1ed0002971416a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"top performing brands on tiktok 4x3\" height=\"1500\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Samantha Lee/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Popular brands like Nike and Chipotle are finding massive success on TikTok. Catherine and I asked four social media and marketing experts which brands they think are currently doing the best on TikTok and why. <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/power-list-top-brands-on-tiktok-include-chipotle-nike-crocs-2020-8\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Here were their top 22 picks.</a></p><p>Among the brands, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/dunkins-tiktok-strategy-includes-charli-damelio-partnership-and-ugc-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Dunkin' stands out for its unique, fan-driven strategy</a> on the platform. I spoke to the team at the coffee chain to hear about how user-generated content and unpaid viral challenges have helped the brand connect with customers on the app.</p><p>Turns out TikTok isn't just for the mainstream. <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/luxury-brands-louis-vuitton-fendi-dior-flock-to-tiktok-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Luxury designers like Louis Vuitton, Fendi, and Dior</a> are also reaching new shoppers on the app.</p><section><h1><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/review-dunkin-krispy-kreme-pumpkin-spice-donuts-comparison-2020-9#the-new-krispy-kreme-donut-this-year-is-the-pumpkin-spice-cinnamon-roll-donut-a-pumpkin-donut-dusted-with-pumpkin-spice-sugar-and-topped-with-swirls-of-cinnamon-and-cream-cheese-frosting-12\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Pumpkin spice donut taste test: Krispy Kreme annihilates Dunkin'</a></h1></section><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f524bbb7ed0ee001e25d7ed?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Pumpkin spice donuts 13\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The new Krispy Kreme donut this year is the pumpkin spice cinnamon roll donut.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Irene Jiang/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>It might only be September, but Pumpkin Spice season is upon us. As such, Irene compared Krispy Kreme's pumpkin spice donut collection to Dunkin's to see which was superior.&#160;</p><p>Spoiler alert: Krispy Kreme won out. The standout donut was the chain's new pumpkin spice cinnamon roll donut, which Irene described as \"absolutely delicious.\"</p><p><em><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/review-dunkin-krispy-kreme-pumpkin-spice-donuts-comparison-2020-9#the-new-krispy-kreme-donut-this-year-is-the-pumpkin-spice-cinnamon-roll-donut-a-pumpkin-donut-dusted-with-pumpkin-spice-sugar-and-topped-with-swirls-of-cinnamon-and-cream-cheese-frosting-12\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Check out the full mouth-watering taste-test here.</a></strong></em></p><h2><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/burger-king-new-restaurants-design-coronavirus-cubbies-kitchens-more-parking-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Chains are changing the design and sizes of their store fleets</a></h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f5245a5e6ff30001d4e7122?format=jpeg\" alt=\"burger king redesign\" height=\"404\" width=\"540\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Burger King</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Chains are revamping how their store fleets function. Here are four examples of major changes:</p><ul><li>Lego is set to open <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/lego-on-track-to-open-120-new-stores-despite-pandemic-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">74 new stores</a> this year, as sales soar 14% during the pandemic.&#160;</li><li>Macy's is opening a slew of smaller stores that are <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/macys-opening-stores-smaller-not-in-mall-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">untethered to malls</a>.</li><li>Burger King's new <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/burger-king-new-restaurants-design-coronavirus-cubbies-kitchens-more-parking-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">restaurants designed for a \"COVID world\"</a> feature no-contact cubbies and lofted kitchens to make room for cars.</li><li>Amazon just had a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/amazon-fresh-grocery-store-exclusive-photos-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">soft opening</a> for its Amazon Fresh store, a&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/inside-amazons-new-grocery-store-amazon-fresh-photos-2020-8\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"e155f6bd275f3e3ef1a2c873fc583ec1\">new grocery concept</a> located in Woodland Hills, California.</li></ul><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 00:37:13","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","title":"If you're an aspiring homeowner, use the 30/30/3 rule to figure out what kind of house you can afford","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/use-30303-rule-determine-what-house-you-can-afford-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ee7dfb8988ee34db77d0267?format=jpeg\" alt=\"realtor showing house couple buying house\" height=\"1414\" width=\"1885\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>It can be tricky to determine what kind of home you can afford as a first-time buyer.\n<p class=\"copyright\">SDI Productions/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Sam Dogen lives in San Francisco with his wife and their young son, and runs the blog <a href=\"https://www.financialsamurai.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener noopenernoopener\" data-uri=\"14e043e4dd631899d3167c5f4d0547e4\">Financial Samurai.</a></li>\n<li>For aspiring homeowners wondering what kind of house they can afford, Dogen recommends using his 30/30/3 homebuying rule.&#160;&#160;</li>\n<li>You should be spending no more than 30% of your gross income on a monthly mortgage payment, have at least 30% of the home's value saved up in cash or semi-liquid assets, and buy a home valued at no more than three times your annual household gross income.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The best home buying rule I can offer you is my 30/30/3 homebuying rule. If you follow my homebuying rule, you will have a greater chance of surviving any financial downturn. Even if you just follow one part of the rule, you will also be able to enjoy your property more because you will be less stressed about your finances.</p><p>Way too many homebuyers overextended themselves during&#160;<a href=\"https://www.financialsamurai.com/personal-lessons-learned-since-the-2008-financial-crisis/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener\" aria-label=\"undefined (opens in a new tab)\">the 2008-2009 financial crisis</a>. As a result, most of us paid the price. Having your neighbor conduct a short sale or foreclosure isn't good for your wealth even if you borrowed well within your means.</p><p>There is a lot of demand for real estate during the pandemic. You can get&#160;<a href=\"https://www.financialsamurai.com/average-30-year-fixed-mortgage-rate-record-low/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener\" aria-label=\"undefined (opens in a new tab)\">a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage for under 3%</a>. The stock market is volatile. Finally, we're all spending way more time at home.</p><p>It is only logical that interest in real estate has increased. However, this is all the more reason to stay disciplined.</p><p>Just look at this national home price appreciation chart during a pandemic. It is accelerating!</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4ea196e6ff30001d4e671e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"financial samurai chart 1\" height=\"362\" width=\"512\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">The Financial Samurai</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>For those of you buying a home during a period of maximum uncertainty, please follow my 30/30/3 homebuying rule. Not only will the rule save you from a lot of stress, but it will also better protect our economy.</p><h2>The 30/30/3 homebuying rule</h2><p>Here are the three homebuying rules to follow. The goal is to follow all three homebuying rules. If you can't, you must follow at least one.</p><h2><strong>Rule No. 1: Spend no more than 30% of your gross income on a monthly mortgage payment</strong></h2><p>Traditionally, the industry says to spend no more than<strong>&#160;</strong>30% of your gross income on your monthly mortgage payment. However, as mortgage rates continue to decline, more people are tempted to increase the percentage.</p><p>When&#160;mortgage rates are lower, you can already buy more home if you keep your spending as a percentage of gross income fixed. The danger emerges when you break this home buying rule percentage to buy an even more expensive home.</p><p>The people most at risk of breaking the first rule of home buying are middle income to lower income people.</p><p>Spending 40% of your monthly $50,000 gross income on a mortgage still leaves you with $30,000 in gross income. However, spending 40% of your monthly $5,000 gross income leaves you with a much smaller cushion.</p><p>You must be able to take care of your basic needs with the remaining money. Therefore, it is safer to spend less of your monthly gross income on a mortgage the more income challenged you are.&#160;</p><h2><strong>Rule No. 2: Have at least 30% of the home value saved up in cash or semi-liquid assets</strong></h2><p>Before buying a home, you should have at least 30% of the value of the home saved in cash.&#160;20% is for the down payment to avoid PMI insurance and get the lowest mortgage rate. The other 10% is for a healthy cash buffer just in case you run into financial trouble.</p><p>I realize that there are programs that allow you to put down a smaller down payment. However, during times of maximum uncertainty, it's better to have a larger financial cushion.</p><p>The homeowners who got blown out the quickest during the previous recession had minimal down payments. With minimal equity, the temptation to walk away from a mortgage is much greater. The thousands who did between 2008 and 2012 missed out on one of the largest real estate recoveries ever.</p><p>If you are planning on buying a home within the next six months, keep at least the 20% down payment in cash. It is unwise to&#160;<a href=\"https://www.financialsamurai.com/how-to-invest-your-down-payment-if-youre-planning-to-buy-a-house/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener\" aria-label=\"undefined (opens in a new tab)\">invest your down-payment</a>&#160;in stocks and other risk assets if your home buying time horizon is so short.</p><p>If you don't have at least 30% of the value of the home saved up, it's time to curtail your desires. Eat ramen noodles for the next six months to save money. Start a side hustle to boost your income.</p><p>Borrowing the down-payment from the Bank of Mom is pretty common nowadays. However, before you do, you need to ensure that you aren't putting your parents at financial risk.</p><h2><strong>Rule No. 3: Limit the value of your target home to no more than three times your annual household gross income</strong></h2><p>Home affordability based on cash flow is a function of the price you pay for the home. If you are able to meet the first two home buying rules, then you can tie it all together with the final home buying rule.</p><p>Rule No. 3 is a quick way for homebuyers to screen for homes in an affordable price range. The rule also takes into consideration down payment percentages and prevents one from stretching too much, even with a high down payment.</p><p>If you earn $100,000 a year, you can comfortably afford up to a $300,000 home. Or maybe you are lucky enough to earn&#160;a top 1% income of $500,000 a year. If so, then you can comfortably afford up to a $1,500,000 home.</p><p>Again, with mortgage rates collapsing, housing affordability has gone up. Therefore, you could stretch the third home buying rule and<strong> extend the home value up to five times</strong>&#160;your annual household income.</p><p>Just know that five times a larger salary not only means more absolute debt, but also higher property taxes, maintenance expenses, and so forth. Make sure you run all the numbers before you make any home purchase.</p><h2>Homebuying examples of<strong> following or closely following the 30/30/3 homebuying rule</strong></h2><p>You make $100,000 a year and have $120,000 in cash saved. You desire to buy a $300,000 home. After putting 20% down, you have a $240,000 mortgage. The monthly payment is $1,012 or just 12% of your monthly gross income. With a $60,000 cash buffer left, you have almost five years of mortgage expense covered.</p><p>With the same income and cash savings, you decide to live it up a little and buy a $400,000 home instead. After putting 20% down, you have a $320,000 mortgage and still have a good $40,000 cash buffer. Your monthly payment is $1,349/month at a 3% mortgage rate. The payment is still only 16% of your monthly gross income of $8,333. This is good compared to the 30% maximum recommendation.</p><p>Thanks to low mortgage rates, you can see how stretching to buy a house worth four times or even five times your annual income is possible. However, I do recommended sticking to a three times multiple if you want that wonderful feeling of financial security.</p><p>If America was filled with homebuyers like this, then the 2008-2009 housing crisis would not have been nearly as bad. Unfortunately, too many homebuyers didn't follow the 30/30/3 homebuying rule. Most of us suffered as a result due to foreclosures and short-sales that brought our property values down.</p><h2><strong>An example of someone not following the 30/30/3 homebuying rule</strong></h2><p>You make $120,000 a year and have $100,000 in cash saved at 32 years old. Not bad. However, you're also salivating for an $850,000 home, which equates to seven times your annual income.</p><p>You can't put 20% down so you only put 10% down. This leaves you with only a $15,000 cash buffer and a $765,000 mortgage.</p><header></header><p>Due to a lower down payment, the best mortgage rate you can get is 3.75%. This is still low by historical standards. However, your monthly payment of $3,543 is 35.4% of your $10,000 gross income. It's probably closer to 40% due to PMI. You have now violated all three of my homebuying rules.</p><p>If you lose your job, you will run out of cash in four months. You may get lucky holding on with enhanced government unemployment benefits and a couple stimulus checks. However, think about how stressed you will be during this time period.</p><p>Instead of buying this home now, first save up another $155,000 to get to $255,000 in cash and semi-liquid investments. With 30% of the home price saved, you can put down 20% and have a nice $85,000 cash cushion.</p><p>Further, your mortgage will decline to $680,000. At a 3.25% mortgage rate, your mortgage payment would be $2,959 or 29.6% of your monthly gross income. If your income increases while you are patiently saving for a larger downpayment, even better.&#160;Shop around for a better rate.</p><h2><strong>An example of a terrible violation of the 30/30/3 rule</strong></h2><p>Rule No. 3 helps prevent a homebuyer from going off the deep end. Sometimes, people confuse their own true buying power with reality. Receiving a windfall can play tricks on some people.</p><p>Let's say you make $70,000 and have a $500,000 down payment due to an inheritance. You feel rich! As a result, you may be tempted to buy a $1 million home since you can put $500,000 down.</p><p>If you do, your $2,316 monthly mortgage payment equals 40% of your monthly gross income. But then you get furloughed shortly after purchase with no pay. Three months into furlough, your boss says they won't ever be hiring you back. You are screwed because you have no cash buffer. You thought the $500,000 windfall would be a regular thing. But people only die once.</p><p>You end up going into foreclosure. Your credit and finances are ruined. The property values on your block all take a hit thanks to you. Your financial life is over for several years.</p><p>Or in one man's case after foreclosing on his home, he went on to get a job at The New York Times as&#160;<a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/09/business/how-a-financial-pro-lost-his-house.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener nofollow nofollow sponsored\" aria-label=\"undefined (opens in a new tab)\">a finance columnist</a>. That's right, even after deciding not pay back his mortgage, he still got a job giving financial advice. Anything is possible folks.</p><h2>Ways to get around the 30/30/3 homebuying rule</h2><p>Although the 30/30/3 homebuying rule may seem stringent in such a low interest rate environment, just know plenty of people pay all-cash for their homes too. This idea of taking on lots of debt to buy property hasn't always been the norm.</p><p>If you want to violate the 30/30/3 homebuying rule, then at least consider the following:</p><ul><li>Rent out a room or a portion of your house</li><li>Create a business&#160;on the side to have a legitimate way to deduct a home office and other expenses like internet</li><li>Be in line for a raise or secure a new job with a raise and promotion</li><li>Build&#160;new passive income streams&#160;to help pay for your homeownership expenses</li><li>Be really good to your parents and rich relatives</li></ul><h2>Have discipline when buying a home</h2><p>I get your desire to own a nice home. I've been a real estate fanatic since I was in college. We want to live life to the fullest now! What's the point in working so hard if we're just going to hoard our cash right?</p><p>A home can be a solid investment. It not only provides shelter, but it can also be rented out. Your home could even appreciate handsomely in value over time. Due to home price appreciation, many people I know have effectively lived for free over the decades.</p><p>Further, if your kid graduates with no employment prospects after four years of college and $200,000 in tuition expense, he can live in one of your investment properties. There would be no need for your adult child to live with you. This option may be worth a lot to some investors.</p><p>Despite all these benefits of investing in real estate, just don't overextend your finances when buying a home. The stress is not worth it.</p><p>For those of you who are looking to achieve financial independence sooner, follow the&#160;<a href=\"https://www.financialsamurai.com/housing-expense-guideline-for-financial-independence/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener\" aria-label=\"undefined (opens in a new tab)\">FI home buying rule</a>. This rule recommends you keep your home expense to no more than 10% of your monthly gross income. If you follow this homebuying rule, your path to financial independence will be much swifter. You may even start feeling as light as a bird.</p><p>At the very least, please follow my 30/30/3 homebuying rule before making one of the biggest purchases of your life. It'll be good for you in the long run. It'll also be great for your neighbors and the entire financial system as there will be less of a chance you'll be foreclosed.&#160;</p><p>Best of luck in your house hunt. Please stay disciplined!</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/use-30303-rule-determine-what-house-you-can-afford-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=aGILyod7LV8:V_heQ8Avoaw:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 13:30:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5ee7dfb8988ee34db77d0267?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"9a83d8608b44226c02581289b710b149","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn24@2020_5/2020/09/04/16-37-32-017_cb499daba0116481.webp","destWidth":1885,"destHeight":1414,"sourceBytes":95800,"destBytes":95800,"author":"insider@insider.com (Sam Dogen)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5ee7dfb8988ee34db77d0267?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn24@2020_5/2020/09/04/16-37-32-017_cb499daba0116481.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f4ea196e6ff30001d4e671e?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn88@2020_4/2020/09/04/16-37-59-517_d38dfb4d1f5b9f96.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn3@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-38-03-978_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=aGILyod7LV8:V_heQ8Avoaw:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn27@2020_5/2020/09/04/16-38-00-952_6540cd3c20da9371.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=aGILyod7LV8:V_heQ8Avoaw:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn95@2020_5/2020/09/04/16-38-03-024_c1bac10e814a64f8.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn24@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-37-59-085_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=aGILyod7LV8:V_heQ8Avoaw:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn12@2020_4/2020/09/04/16-38-03-247_1c0d97348adfbc4d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/aGILyod7LV8":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn40@2020_2/2020/09/04/16-37-54-227_d4d0b8bf1a3ecd23.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599237433650},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","title":"I've been using Samsung's new $2,000 foldable phone for a day — here are 5 things that stood out to me the most","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/samsung-galaxy-z-fold-2-best-features-new-foldable-phone-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f524ccbe6ff30001d4e716a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 2 Open Back\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Lisa Eadicicco/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Samsung is getting ready to launch its third foldable smartphone, the $2,000 Galaxy Z Fold.</li>\n<li>The new model comes with some major improvements over the original Galaxy Fold, such as a larger cover screen and a more durable design.</li>\n<li>It also has impressively loud speakers for a smartphone.</li>\n<li>But at $2,000, it's still a tough sell for most people.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Samsung became the first major smartphone maker to introduce a foldable phone in early 2019 with the debut of <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/samsung-galaxy-fold-review-2019-4\">the original Galaxy Fold</a>, beating rivals like Huawei and Motorola to the punch.</p><p>But that approach seemingly backfired for the South Korean tech giant. The company delayed the phone's launch by several months after some reviewers reported that their device had broken after just two days of use.&#160;</p><p>Now, Samsung is on its third foldable device, the Galaxy Z Fold 2, a successor to the original Fold that also inherits some qualities of the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/samsung-galaxy-z-flip-new-foldable-smartphone-photos-hands-on-2020-2\">Galaxy Z Flip</a> it launched earlier this year. But it'll put quite a strain on your wallet when it launches on September 18. The Galaxy Z Fold 2 costs $2,000, making it slightly more expensive than its predecessor and the $1,450 Galaxy Z Flip.</p><p>Even with its improved, more durable design, the Galaxy Z Fold 2 isn't for everyone — the price alone is enough to make anyone question whether it's a worthwhile decision. And there's certainly a learning curve that comes with using a phone with such an irregular design compared too your typical smartphone.</p><p>At this stage, foldable phones are still best-suited for early adopters that don't mind spending a lot of money up front and taking the risks that come with buying a product that might be a little ahead of its time. Foldable phones are still in their awkward teen phase so to speak: phone makers still need some time to work out the growing pains.&#160;&#160;</p><p>But even after just a day with it, the Galaxy Z Fold 2 gives me confidence that things will progress quickly. It addresses some of the original Fold's biggest setbacks, particularly when it comes to the size of its cover screen and durability. Samsung claims the new sweeper hinge will keep dust and debris from damaging the device, as was the case with the first Galaxy Fold.&#160;</p><p>Here's a look at some of the aspects about the Galaxy Z Fold 2 that immediately stood out to me.&#160;</p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tThe Galaxy Z Fold 2 has an improved design with bigger cover screen.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f524cf07ed0ee001e25d805?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 2 Cover Screen\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Lisa Eadicicco/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Compared to the original Galaxy Fold, there are several improvements when it comes to design.</p><p>Among the biggest is the significantly larger cover screen on the front of the device. The Galaxy Z Fold 2's front screen measures 6.2 inches, making it roughly the same size as the display on the Galaxy S20 (although the Z Fold 2's screen is noticeably narrower).</p><p>That's a major upgrade compared to the 4.6-inch cover display on the original Galaxy Fold, which felt too cramped and tiny to actually be useful.</p><p>I've actually been using the front screen on the Galaxy Z Fold 2 to quickly check Slack messages and send text messages &#8212; basic tasks that were difficult or impossible on the older Fold's tiny front screen.&#160;</p>\n\tThe crease is also much less noticeable.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f524d157ed0ee001e25d808?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 2 Open Apps\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Lisa Eadicicco/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>The other aspect of the Galaxy Z Fold 2's design that stood out to me was how subtle the crease in the middle of the display seemed compared with last year's version.</p><p>When I reviewed the Galaxy Fold in April 2019, I wrote that the crease was noticeable when performing everyday tasks like reading a news article, checking social media, and sifting through my email inbox. The crease may seem apparent in the image above, and it's not completely invisible, but it's still much less intrusive in everyday use compared to last year's model.</p><p>That's important because the whole appeal of a foldable device like the Galaxy Z Fold is its larger, tablet-sized screen. A less noticeable crease makes the Galaxy Z Flip all the more useful in this mode when unfolded.&#160;</p>\n\tBut it's still heavier than your average phone — and very thick.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f524d757ed0ee001e25d80a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 2 Thickness\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The iPhone 11 Pro beneath the Galaxy Z Fold 2.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Lisa Eadicicco/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>The Galaxy Z Fold 2 isn't for those who frequently stuff their phone into a tight jeans pocket or a small purse. When folded, the Galaxy Z Fold 2 is essentially as thick as two phones stacked on top of one another, making it difficult to fit in tight spaces.</p><p>The device's thickness also generally takes some getting used to when holding the device while closed in one hand. Its larger size also means its heavier than your average smartphone; the Galaxy Z Fold 2 weighs 282 grams, while the Galaxy S20 weighs 163 grams. The iPhone 11 Pro, which is pictured underneath the Galaxy Z Fold 2 above, only weighs 188 grams by comparison.</p>\n\tFlex Mode makes the Galaxy Z Fold 2 more useful as a camera.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f524dd87ed0ee001e25d80e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 2 Camera\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Lisa Eadicicco/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>When I tried the Galaxy Z Flip earlier this year, one of my favorite things about it was its ability to stay propped open halfway, with the bottom half of the phone propping it up like a tripod.</p><p>Thankfully, the Galaxy Z Fold 2 has inherited this feature. Launching the camera and opening the phone horizontally will prompt the device to display the camera viewfinder on the top half of the screen. The bottom half houses camera controls like the shutter button and the most recent photo from your camera roll.&#160;</p><p>If you've ever scrambled to prop your phone up on a nearby surface when trying to take a group photo with friends or family, I imagine you'll appreciate the Galaxy Z Fold's ability to keep its camera upright on its own.</p>\n\tIts speakers are louder than I've heard on any phone.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f524e9ae6ff30001d4e717c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 2 Speakers\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Lisa Eadicicco/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>The Galaxy Z Fold 2's stereo speakers are plenty loud and boisterous &#8212; a must for a large-screened device like this that was likely designed with entertainment in mind.</p><p>The phone's speakers sounded impressively crisp with the volume cranked all the way up, pumping out tunes that sounded much clearer and more powerful compared to the iPhone 11 Pro Max's. Apple's high-end iPhone sounded shallower in comparison, and wasn't quite as loud.&#160;</p>\n\tOverall, the Galaxy Z Fold 2 feels like exactly what Samsung wanted the original Fold to be.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f524e3ee6ff30001d4e717a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 2 back\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Lisa Eadicicco/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Samsung didn't need to rush out the original Galaxy Fold in 2019 to beat its rivals. The Galaxy Z Fold 2 is still one of only a few foldable phones on the market, and it feels much more like a finished product that's ready for consumers, unlike the original Fold.</p><p>The debacle that occurred with Samsung's first foldable phone also means it's already learned from its mistakes and has been able to iterate at a time when other major players like Google and Apple have yet to announce plans to launch a foldable phone.</p><p>But at $2,000, the Galaxy Z Fold 2 is likely going to be a tough sell for most people, especially coming at a time when the coronavirus pandemic has hammered the economy and put many people out of work.&#160;</p><p>The Galaxy Z Fold 2 is evidence that tech giants like Samsung are continuing to think about the evolution of the modern smartphone. It will be quite some time before foldable phones replace the sleek rectangles we carry around today &#8212; if they every do at all &#8212; but the Z Fold 2 is certainly another step in that direction.</p>\n</div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/samsung-galaxy-z-fold-2-best-features-new-foldable-phone-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=qonIUPA2ywY:Lr6G-5MgC6M:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=qonIUPA2ywY:Lr6G-5MgC6M:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qonIUPA2ywY:Lr6G-5MgC6M:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=qonIUPA2ywY:Lr6G-5MgC6M:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qonIUPA2ywY:Lr6G-5MgC6M:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=qonIUPA2ywY:Lr6G-5MgC6M:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=qonIUPA2ywY:Lr6G-5MgC6M:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qonIUPA2ywY:Lr6G-5MgC6M:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/qonIUPA2ywY\"
