border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=Q2HudsFAHOo:oQeJpd1221g:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Q2HudsFAHOo:oQeJpd1221g:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=Q2HudsFAHOo:oQeJpd1221g:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Q2HudsFAHOo:oQeJpd1221g:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=Q2HudsFAHOo:oQeJpd1221g:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=Q2HudsFAHOo:oQeJpd1221g:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Q2HudsFAHOo:oQeJpd1221g:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/Q2HudsFAHOo\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 16:33:12 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f526853e6ff30001d4e7241?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"8a47c999a78451585b689a943f1238d2","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn63@2020_5/2020/09/04/16-37-50-059_b9e2d529dbccd868.webp","destWidth":2910,"destHeight":2182,"sourceBytes":316074,"destBytes":316074,"author":"grapier@businessinsider.com (Graham Rapier,Reuters)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f52684a7ed0ee001e25d8d4?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn39@2020_2/2020/09/04/16-38-02-353_ceae5cca4ba0afa3.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn3@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-38-03-978_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Q2HudsFAHOo:oQeJpd1221g:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn35@2020_4/2020/09/04/16-37-52-742_9f22e6e90a24cc8c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Q2HudsFAHOo:oQeJpd1221g:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn23@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-38-04-917_d3a99f73c17e194b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn24@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-37-59-085_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Q2HudsFAHOo:oQeJpd1221g:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn55@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-37-59-414_796ce4cc4e00bead.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/Q2HudsFAHOo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn92@2020_4/2020/09/04/16-38-02-980_8049a32d4953db58.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599237433647},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","title":"How to use Portrait mode on your iPhone's camera to take professional-quality photos","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-use-portrait-mode-on-iphone","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f51342fe6ff30001d4e6eb0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"teens taking iphone selfie camera\" height=\"1249\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>It&#39;s easy to take great photos with iPhone&#39;s Portrait mode feature.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Tomas Rodriguez/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>You can use Portrait mode on your iPhone to take high-quality photos, as long your iPhone has at least two camera lenses built in.&#160;</li>\n<li>Portrait mode simulates the shallow depth of field in high-quality portraits taken with an SLR camera.&#160;</li>\n<li>When you turn on Portrait mode in the Camera app, be sure the lighting mode turns yellow before you snap the photo.</li>\n<li>You can change the photo's depth of field after the photo is taken using the Portrait mode controls in the Photos app.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-reference\"><strong>Visit Business Insider's Tech Reference library for more stories</strong></a><strong>.</strong></li>\n</ul><p>When the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/iphone\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">iPhone's</a> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/portrait-mode\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Portrait mode</a> debuted on the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/iphone-7-plus\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">iPhone 7 Plus</a>, it was the first smartphone to mimic the effect of taking a portrait with shallow depth of field, like you can with a professional SLR camera.&#160;</p><p>Now, many iPhone models let you take portraits with this feature. Your iPhone needs at least two camera lenses since it's taking two separate photos (one of the subject and another of the background) and combining them using artificial intelligence.&#160;</p><h2><strong>Which iPhones can use Portrait mode</strong></h2><p>You can find Portrait mode in the Camera app on many iPhones. Here is the list of compatible devices right now:</p><ul><li>iPhone 7 Plus</li><li>iPhone 8 Plus</li><li>iPhone X, iPhone XR, iPhone XS, and iPhone XS Max</li><li>iPhone 11, iPhone 11 Pro, and iPhone 11 Pro Max</li><li>iPhone SE (2nd generation, 2020)</li></ul><p>If you have an iPhone X or later, you can also use Portrait mode to take a selfie.&#160;</p><h2><strong>How to use Portrait mode on iPhone</strong></h2><p><strong>1.</strong> Start the Camera app and then tap or swipe in the menu at the bottom of the screen to choose \"Portrait.\"</p><p><strong>2.</strong> Wait until the lighting mode turns yellow to indicate it's ready for you to take the shot. The default lighting mode is Natural Light, though you can swipe through the other options. No matter which one you choose, wait for it to turn yellow.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f512fae7ed0ee001e25d50c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"ios13 iphone11 pro camera portrait lighting 1\" height=\"1602\" width=\"800\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Select the lighting mode you want to use in your portrait and wait for it to turn yellow before taking the photo.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Apple</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p><strong>3.</strong> If you have an iPhone X or later, you can switch to the front camera to take a selfie.&#160;</p><p><strong>4.</strong> Tap the circular Shutter button to take the picture.&#160;</p><p>If you don't have enough light, or there isn't enough contrast between the subject and background, the Camera app might display a message at the top of the screen with advice on how to change your composition.&#160;</p><h2><strong>How to adjust the depth of field in a Portrait photo</strong></h2><p>The magic ingredient in a Portrait mode photo is the ability to have an out-of-focus background with a razor-sharp subject. With an SLR camera, you'd get this effect by using an aperture with a small f-number, like f2 or f4. The iPhone lets you adjust the aperture after the fact.&#160;</p><p><strong>1.</strong> Start the Photos app and find the Portrait mode photo you want to edit.&#160;</p><p><strong>2.</strong> Tap \"Edit\" in the upper right corner of the screen.&#160;</p><p><strong>3.</strong> At the top left of the screen you should see the f-number associated with the photo. Tap it.&#160;</p><p><strong>4.</strong> At the bottom of the photo, you should see a slider with all the available f-numbers for the photo. Swipe to the left or right and watch how the background changes. Smaller f-numbers will make the background blurrier, while larger numbers make it sharper.&#160;</p><p><strong>5.</strong> When you're satisfied, tap \"Done.\" You can return to this screen and change the depth of field at any time.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f513096e6ff30001d4e6ea1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Apple iphone portrait mode edit\" height=\"1600\" width=\"800\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>You can &#34;dial in&#34; the photo&#39;s depth of field after it&#39;s taken.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Apple</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2><strong>How to turn off Portrait mode in a photo</strong></h2><p>It's easy to remove the portrait effect from a photo. In fact, you can toggle it on and off at any time.&#160;</p><p><strong>1.</strong> Start the Photos app and find the Portrait mode photo you want to edit.&#160;</p><p><strong>2.</strong> Tap \"Edit\" in the upper right corner of the screen.&#160;</p><p><strong>3.</strong> At the top of the screen you should see the label \"Portrait.\" To turn off Portrait mode, tap it, and it will turn into white text on a black background. To turn Portrait mode for this photo back on, tap again and it should turn yellow.&#160;&#160;</p><div id=\"ProductCard_5d8e19fb2e22af18f40d281d\" style=\"position:relative; display:block; width: 100%\"><iframe src=\"https://produktor.businessinsider.com/productCardService?id=5d8e19fb2e22af18f40d281d&type=small&live=true\" width=\"100%\" height=\"150%\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\" style=\"position:absolute; top:0; left: 0\"></iframe></div><h2><strong>Related coverage from&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\">Tech Reference</a>:</strong></h2><ul><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/why-wont-my-iphone-camera-work\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\">'Why won't my iPhone camera work?': How to fix your iPhone camera if it's malfunctioning<br></a></h3></li><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-set-timer-on-iphone-camera\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\">How to set a timer on your iPhone camera, and take a picture after a brief countdown</a></h3></li><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/why-is-my-iphone-camera-black\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\">'Why space and sending larger files</a></h3></li><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-select-multiple-photos-on-iphone\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=w-WS3Jb196k:x_2QHYQRXCs:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=w-WS3Jb196k:x_2QHYQRXCs:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/w-WS3Jb196k\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 16:35:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f51341f7ed0ee001e25d524?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"50f6c9f479b76b5553c1accccf762401","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn4@2020_2/2020/09/04/16-37-43-806_dded92e693eecfe3.webp","destWidth":2222,"destHeight":1666,"sourceBytes":80038,"destBytes":80038,"author":"insider@insider.com (Dave Johnson)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f51342fe6ff30001d4e6eb0?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn71@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-37-48-739_eab7f1f1a02fb60b.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f512fae7ed0ee001e25d50c?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn67@2020_2/2020/09/04/16-38-06-082_97229d8abf47c82c.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f513096e6ff30001d4e6ea1?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn83@2020_5/2020/09/04/16-37-58-384_e200adc4113904bd.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn3@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-38-03-978_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=w-WS3Jb196k:x_2QHYQRXCs:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn59@2020_3/2020/09/04/16-37-45-161_eb8be06d4d11987c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=w-WS3Jb196k:x_2QHYQRXCs:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn39@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-38-05-851_cb160263032dfe76.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn24@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-37-59-085_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=w-WS3Jb196k:x_2QHYQRXCs:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn31@2020_2/2020/09/04/16-37-59-273_21d3997b91b16932.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/w-WS3Jb196k":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn27@2020_3/2020/09/04/16-38-07-423_32ac2199607771f8.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599237433656},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","title":"We just got promising early data on Russia's experimental coronavirus vaccine, and now scientists will run a large trial to see if the shot works","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-coronavirus-vaccine-data-lancet-early-positive-human-results-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f408f3c89aff80028ab756b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"russia coronavirus vaccine\" height=\"1610\" width=\"2146\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Medical workers prepare to draw blood from volunteers participating in Russia&#39;s trial of a coronavirus vaccine.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Russian Defense Ministry Press Service via AP, File</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The first results for Russia's coronavirus vaccine candidate are encouraging but limited by the small size of the trials.</li>\n<li>Russian researchers published the initial data Friday in The Lancet. It comes nearly a month after Russian officials <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-approves-coronavirus-vaccine-experts-say-needs-more-testing-2020-8\">touted a provisional approval of the shot</a>.</li>\n<li>Two studies found the vaccine was generally safe and produced immune responses in a group of 76 young and healthy volunteers.</li>\n<li>Despite the early approval, the authors of the study acknowledged the need to run a larger study. They said Russia was planning a 40,000-volunteer trial to determine if the vaccine prevents infection or disease.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>A Russian coronavirus vaccine candidate was generally safe and produced encouraging immune responses in early studies involving 76 young and healthy volunteers.&#160;</p><p>The data, <a href=\"https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(20)31866-3/fulltext\">published Friday in The Lancet</a>, is the first glimpse at clinical results for Russia's leading vaccine. Nearly a month ago, Russian officials <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-approves-coronavirus-vaccine-experts-say-needs-more-testing-2020-8\">issued a provisional approval</a> for the shot, and President Vladimir Putin <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/putin-russia-has-coronavirus-vaccine-daughter-despite-concerns-development-2020-8\">said one of his daughters had received the vaccine</a>.</p><p>While the data is encouraging, it comes from early and small trials. The Russian authors of the report acknowledged that more studies would be needed to determine if the vaccine works. The country is now planning a 40,000-volunteer phase-three trial that will include a wider variety of people, they said.&#160;</p><p><em><strong>Read more: </strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-vaccine-timeline-what-to-watch-leading-research-2020-3\">There are 176 coronavirus vaccines in the works. Here's how the top drugmakers see the race for a cure playing out in 2020 and 2021 and when the first shots might be available.</a></em></p><p>All observed side effects from the vaccine were mild or moderate, with the vast majority being mild, according to the study. The most common side effects were pain at injection site (58%), increase in body temperature (50%), headache (42%), tiredness or weakness (28%), and muscle and joint pain (24%).</p><p>And while the studies recorded encouraging immune responses, it's still not clear which type of immune response might protect people from infection or disease. The researchers said levels of neutralizing antibodies, virus-fighting proteins that play a critical role in warding off invading germs, were lower in the Russian study than in reports from other leading vaccine candidates developed with different technologies.</p><p><em><strong>Read more: </strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/list-of-catalysts-in-september-for-coronavirus-vaccines-and-treatments-2020-8\">We could get crucial data on top coronavirus vaccines and treatments this month. Here are the 10 most important events to watch for.</a></em></p><p>Two public-health experts at Johns Hopkins University, who were not involved in this study, called the results \"encouraging but small.\"&#160;</p><p>\"The immunogenicity bodes well, although nothing can be inferred on immunogenicity in older age groups, and clinical efficacy for any COVID-19 vaccine has not yet been shown,\" Dr. Naor Bar-Zeev and Dr. Tom Inglesby wrote in <a href=\"https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(20)31867-5/fulltext\">a related comment in The Lancet</a>.</p><p><em><strong>Read more: </strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/moncef-slaoui-exclusive-interview-warp-speed-coronavirus-vaccine-2020-8\">We spoke to Trump's coronavirus vaccine czar about when he anticipates getting a coronavirus vaccine, the secrecy around Operation Warp Speed, and his typical day that starts at 2:30 a.m.</a></em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-coronavirus-vaccine-data-lancet-early-positive-human-results-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ObSwfZrlGd0:iJMbkZOMH5U:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/ObSwfZrlGd0\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 13:26:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f408f3c89aff80028ab756b?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"e7871b134aac06921743b1196033d962","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn28@2020_5/2020/09/04/16-37-30-064_e11903b2dfbe2f72.webp","destWidth":2146,"destHeight":1610,"sourceBytes":160988,"destBytes":160988,"author":"adunn@businessinsider.com (Andrew Dunn)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f408f3c89aff80028ab756b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn28@2020_5/2020/09/04/16-37-30-064_e11903b2dfbe2f72.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn3@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-38-03-978_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ObSwfZrlGd0:iJMbkZOMH5U:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn32@2020_4/2020/09/04/16-37-54-666_a6e37abbb9236602.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ObSwfZrlGd0:iJMbkZOMH5U:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn75@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-37-57-165_7bbf793a4e0d0908.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn24@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-37-59-085_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ObSwfZrlGd0:iJMbkZOMH5U:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn52@2020_4/2020/09/04/16-38-04-324_6e878dae181a2ad3.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/ObSwfZrlGd0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn15@2020_2/2020/09/04/16-37-57-659_6b0acd32f5d400c7.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599237433647},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","title":"A homeless Detroit man bought an abandoned house for $1,500 and spent 10 years renovating it for his wife. Here's how he did it — and what it looks like now.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/homeless-college-graduate-buys-detroit-home-renovation-photos-2019-11","description":"<figure> \n <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dbf067de0ee7e6d8a77c483?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_5828.JPG\" height=\"1727\" width=\"2303\" charset=\"\"> \n  <figcaption>\n   Michael and Cynthia Gray. \n   <p class=\"copyright\">Michael Gray</p> \n  </figcaption> </img>\n</figure>\n<ul class=\"summary-list\">\n <li><strong>In 2009, Michael Gray, a native Detroiter, bought an abandoned home from his nephew for just $1,500. He moved in as soon as he bought it.&nbsp;<br /></strong></li>\n <li><strong>Before purchasing the home, Gray told Business Insider that he was homeless and living in his niece's basement.</strong></li>\n <li><strong>In 2010, he began a nearly 10-year renovation process and transformed the home room by room.</strong></li>\n <li><strong>In an interview with Business Insider, Gray explained how he turned the home into a livable space for both him and his wife.</strong></li>\n <li><strong>His home is now in a housing market that is booming, according to local reports.</strong></li>\n <li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</strong></li>\n</ul>\n<p>Michael Gray is a native Detroiter.</p>\n<p>At 67 years old, he spends his weekdays working as a machinist in Bowling Green, Ohio, and his weekends at his home in Detroit with his wife, Cynthia.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>The story of their four-bedroom home dates back to November 2009, when Gray bought it from his nephew for just $1,500.</p>\n<p>Before purchasing the home, Gray was living in his niece's basement. He told Business Insider he was homeless and that despite having a college degree, he was unable to find work in Detroit.</p>\n<p>Gray told Business Insider that after getting hit by a car in 2008, he used some of the settlement money to buy the property. He moved in the day he bought it with nothing but an air mattress to sleep on. At the time, the home was in bad shape. According to Gray, it was infested with mites, spiders, and mice — not even the toilet worked.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>Now, nearly a decade later, Gray is still living there during the coronavirus pandemic and the home is unrecognizable. The market it sits in is booming during the COVID era, too. <a href=\"https://www.wxyz.com/rebound/metro-detroit-housing-market-sees-boom-during-covid-19-pandemic\">According to WXYZ Detroit</a>, real estate listings in the city are currently seeing multiple offers and home showings in the area are up.</p>\n<p>Keep reading for a look at Gray's home transformation below. He compiled photos in two hard-copy albums, which he mailed to Business Insider. In a phone interview, he explained the work that went into renovating the home.</p> \n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n  Michael Gray's house is in Detroit, right outside the University District. It's about one mile from the University of Detroit Mercy. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dc2d1de7eece51846166094?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Detroit\" height=\"1254\" width=\"1672\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.google.com/maps\" target=\"_blank\">Google Maps</a></p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> \n <p>Detroit was once home to the booming auto industry. In the&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.vox.com/2014/12/15/18073574/detroit-bankruptcy-pensions-municipal\">1950s</a>, the auto industry started declining, and companies started <a href=\"https://www.vox.com/2014/12/15/18073574/detroit-bankruptcy-pensions-municipal\">moving out</a> of the city. By the <a href=\"https://www.vox.com/2014/12/15/18073574/detroit-bankruptcy-pensions-municipal\">1960s</a>, people were leaving Detroit in droves.</p>\n <p>In 2013, the city filed for&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.npr.org/2018/12/28/680629749/out-of-bankruptcy-detroit-reaches-financial-milestone\">Chapter 9 bankruptcy protection</a>. Now, more than five years later, more and more people are investing in the city.</p>\n <p>Just consider the entrepreneur <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/homes-in-detroit-selling-for-one-thousand-dollars-2019-7\">Dan Gilbert</a>, the billionaire founder of Quicken Loans. As Business Insider previously reported, after Gilbert moved his company to downtown Detroit in 2010, he started the real-estate firm Bedrock. Not only is Quicken Loans now one of Detroit's largest employers and taxpayers, but as of 2018, Bedrock had also invested or allocated <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/homes-in-detroit-selling-for-one-thousand-dollars-2019-7\">$5.6 billion in roughly 100 properties in downtown Detroit and nearby neighborhoods</a>.</p>\n <p>Now, Detroit's housing market is booming</p> Gray documented the entire renovation process in two large photo albums, which he mailed to Business Insider. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dc2d3973afd3716101b22e4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_1549 2\" height=\"2268\" width=\"3024\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Michael Gray</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> In 2009, he bought the house from his nephew Sylvester for $1,500. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dbc7149e0ee7e111e398f24?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_5809.JPG\" height=\"890\" width=\"1187\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Michael Gray</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Sylvester is a broker for Global Property Investment Group, a commercial real-estate agency. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dbb309ae0ee7e2da73b97ac?format=jpeg\" alt=\"kitchen \" height=\"726\" width=\"968\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption>\n    The kitchen before renovations began. \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Michael Gray</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> \n <p>The company acquires properties from a variety of different sources. When properties don't fit into the company's business model, they are sold to independent purchasers, which is how Gray came across the house.</p> The house was in a state of total disrepair when he bought it. Photos show that paint was peeling off the walls, wires were hanging loose, and the bathroom appliances were covered in rust. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dbb31572f364a2e105eee08?format=jpeg\" alt=\"bathroom\" height=\"677\" width=\"903\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption>\n    The bathroom before renovations began. \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Michael Gray</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Despite its poor condition, Gray moved into the home right away. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dbb1b3be0ee7e0b42382a64?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_5770\" height=\"1770\" width=\"2360\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption>\n    Wires hanging from the wall before renovations began. \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Michael Gray</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> \n <p>\"In Detroit, if you're not there, or you don't have someone there, someone will come in and take your stuff. It's gone in a matter of 15 minutes, gone,\" he explained to Business Insider.</p> When he moved in, the house was infested with mites, spiders, and mice. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dbafb85dee0195ba8029d94?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_5778 2\" height=\"1776\" width=\"2368\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption>\n    The old crawl space behind the master bedroom. \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Michael Gray</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> He wasn't even able to use the toilet. \"The plumbing wasn't working. We were not able to use the toilet at all,\" he said. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dbaf408dee019577400253c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_5793\" height=\"1196\" width=\"1594\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Michael Gray</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> In the beginning, he slept on an air mattress upstairs and renovated the place room by room. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dbaf2d3dee019549a228ac6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_5786\" height=\"1842\" width=\"2456\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Michael Gray</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Before buying the house, Gray was homeless. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dbb57432f364a66cd7f6dec?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Michael Gray\" height=\"1754\" width=\"2339\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Michal Gray</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> \"I had been going through a rough time in my life,\" he said. \"I was staying with my niece and sleeping in her basement.\" \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dbb20a62f364a140d22d214?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_5761\" height=\"1774\" width=\"2365\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption>\n    The process of moving the bathroom wall back a foot to make more room. \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Michael Gray</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Even with a college degree, Gray told Business Insider that he wasn't able to find a job in Detroit. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dbb1b2ce0ee7e0b340d25e2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_5769\" height=\"1662\" width=\"2216\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Michael Gray</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> \n <p>Gray graduated from Spring Arbor University in 1986. He double-majored in English and psychology. While he was living in his niece's basement, he told Business Insider that he worked as a day laborer.</p>\n <p>\"I also began to craft my rehab skills working as a laborer for guys who were fixing up homes to rent,\" he said.</p> But in 2008, his life changed. While riding his bike, he was hit by a car. Using money from the settlement he received from the accident, Gray was able to purchase the abandoned property. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dbafd94dee01969376c7f67?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_5774 2\" height=\"1686\" width=\"2248\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption>\n    The demolition of the ceiling in the living room. \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Michael Gray</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> When describing the renovation project, Gray called it a complete rehab. \"I tore everything out, all the way down to the studs,\" he said. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dbb2072e0ee7e136628eee8?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_5750\" height=\"1752\" width=\"2336\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Michael Gray</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> His wife, Cynthia, who at the time was his fiancée, was there through it all. \"My wife had been with me through thick and thin, and I told her that I was going to give her a house that she would be really proud to keep, live in, and show off,\" he said. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dbb27c8e0ee7e1f2f5a47e2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_5751\" height=\"1789\" width=\"2385\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Michael Gray</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Gray said he did about 80% of the labor himself, including the flooring and the painting. His vision was to \"make it a family home forever.\" \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dbaf3afdee01956a2144fc6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_5795\" height=\"1546\" width=\"2061\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Michael Gray</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> He learned how to do most of the work during his time as an administrative assistant for a construction-management company in Michigan. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dbc501d2f364a5bde3335d8?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_5807.JPG\" height=\"1536\" width=\"2048\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Michael Gray</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> \n <p>\"I was on a project in Monroe, Michigan,\" he told Business Insider. \"When I was part of that renovation team, I watched the guys, I asked questions, and I said, 'I can do this.'\"</p> But for the projects he couldn't do himself, his friends helped out. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dbb4bee2f364a575329c903?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Michael Gray\" height=\"1807\" width=\"2409\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Michael Gray</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> They helped him install, along with other things, the drywall, the electrical box, a new furnace, a hot-water tank, and central air. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dbb2153e0ee7e14825dcc39?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_5767\" height=\"1521\" width=\"2028\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption>\n    Gray overseeing the roof replacement. \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Michael Gray</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Gray told Business Insider that the hardest part of the renovation process was fixing the broken beams in the ceilings. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dbaf3c7dee01956fd7fa1f2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_5784\" height=\"1783\" width=\"2377\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Michael Gray</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> On the flip side, he said the easiest part was the tiling. \"It was hard work, but I enjoyed doing the tiling because if you put a lot of love into what you do, your floors reflect a lot of who you are,\" he said. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dbc5f36e0ee7e7591451875?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_5813\" height=\"1512\" width=\"2016\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Michael Gray</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> When he neared the completion of each room, Gray would stain, sand, and polish everything. \"She had picked out the paint she wanted for each room and, after the drywall went up, I put the primer on and painted. I was closing out the rooms as we completed them,\" he told Business Insider, referring to Cynthia. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dbc50b72f364a5ceb4b83aa?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_20191031_163504\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Michael Gray</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> The major parts of the renovation process were completed in July 2012. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dbc512a2f364a5de946bc4a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_20191031_163242\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Michael Gray</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> The home now has three renovated bedrooms ... \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dbc50082f364a5ba07fc679?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_20191031_164536\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Michael Gray</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> ... and one bathroom. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dbc50c7e0ee7e5f147555a8?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_20191031_163628\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Michael Gray</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> There could be four bedrooms, but they decided to convert one of the rooms into a walk-in closet. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dbc51462f364a5e24444287?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_20191031_163949\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Michael Gray</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Gray told Business Insider that he is constantly working to improve the home. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dbc51c2e0ee7e610c3156f3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_20191031_163553\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Michael Gray</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> So far, he's invested about $70,000 into repairs. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dc3058f7eece56fe10e88c3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Detroit\" height=\"1031\" width=\"1374\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.google.com/maps\" target=\"_blank\">Google Maps</a></p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Michael and Cynthia Gray celebrated their 10th wedding anniversary in November 2019 at the home. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dbf067de0ee7e6d8a77c483?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_5828.JPG\" height=\"1727\" width=\"2303\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption>\n    Michael and Cynthia Gray. \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Michael Gray</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> \n <p><em>This article is part of Business Insider's ongoing series, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/how-i-renovated-it\">How I Renovated It</a>, where we talk to homeowners around the country about the process, budget, and transformation that goes into a renovation. If you have a story you'd like to share, get in touch with <a href=\"mailto:lbrandt@businessinsider.com\">lbrandt@businessinsider.com</a>.</em></p> \n</div>\n<div class=\"read-original\">\n Read the 5dbc50c7e0ee7e5f147555a8?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn44@2020_3/2020/09/04/16-37-59-202_d598fe2269cb098a.webp","https://i.insider.com/5dbc51462f364a5e24444287?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn67@2020_2/2020/09/04/16-37-51-810_4fd8f3ef1ab8b3ab.webp","https://i.insider.com/5dbc51c2e0ee7e610c3156f3?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn8@2020_2/2020/09/04/16-37-57-444_1b5af9f1c1bf6cdb.webp","https://i.insider.com/5dc3058f7eece56fe10e88c3?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn68@2020_5/2020/09/04/16-37-58-285_bdb0287121a45ee6.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn3@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-38-03-978_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=g5vTrL9Cqts:J4vM4FKMZDo:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn8@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-37-48-848_8171de52a916d1d0.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=g5vTrL9Cqts:J4vM4FKMZDo:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn36@2020_2/2020/09/04/16-38-00-168_4b023c102f6b1c1f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn24@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-37-59-085_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=g5vTrL9Cqts:J4vM4FKMZDo:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn63@2020_2/2020/09/04/16-37-57-140_01cd86d7b442b41e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/g5vTrL9Cqts":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn91@2020_4/2020/09/04/16-37-59-612_356cefdbc16bc974.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599237433655},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","title":"Insider Transportation: EV startups take a new road to public markets, airlines ditch change fees, and more","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/insider-transportation-ev-startups-take-a-new-road-to-public-markets-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f525036e6ff30001d4e718b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"canoo 4\" height=\"1253\" width=\"1671\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Canoo is just one of a flock of EV startups skipping the traditional IPO in favor of a reverse merger.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.canoo.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Canoo</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Even amid plagues, summer is the time for road trips. (Maybe especially amid plagues, when travel restrictions make a terrestrial trip <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-road-trip-safely-during-coronavirus-checklist-2020-6\">more workable than flying</a>.) But as we head into Labor Day and take a look back at the season, we've noticed a distinct lack of road <em>shows</em>.</p><p>You know, those continent-hopping bonanzas that serve as the prelude to a company's bell-ringing IPO. And it's not because America's small corporations are sitting tight and riding out the storm (the plaque thing again). In the electric and autonomous vehicle space alone, six companies have gone public or announced plans to do so in the past few months. They've just taken a new route to the public market.</p><p>Electrified-vehicle makers Nikola, Fisker, Lordstown Motors, and Canoo are all going public via a reverse merger with a special-purpose acquisition company. Those entities, better known as SPACs, raise money, go public, and buy another company, which then becomes publicly traded as well.&#160;</p><p>It's not just upstart automakers giving this a go. The CEO of lidar company Luminar, Austin Russell, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/luminar-ceo-changed-mind-ipo-pandemic-nikola-fisker-2020-8\">opted for a reverse merger</a> after watching Nikola do it — and sold his business in <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/25-year-old-sells-startup-founded-high-school-34-billion-2020-8\">a $3.4 billion deal</a>. Solid-state battery venture Quantumscape, which is backed by Volkswagen, <a href=\"https://www.greencarreports.com/news/1129497_vw-backed-solid-state-battery-firm-quantumscape-is-going-public\">declared</a> it's following suit on Thursday.</p><p>Russell hesitated to take this route with Luminar — reverse mergers have long been derided as \"second-rate deals,\" <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/luminar-ceo-changed-mind-ipo-pandemic-nikola-fisker-2020-8\">he told us</a>. But as the trend picked up adherents, he took another look and bought into the idea that <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nikola-fisker-canoo-rejecting-method-tesla-uber-ipo-2020-9\">going with a SPAC isn't just faster and more convenient</a> than a traditional IPO —&#160;it's a great way to accrue some credibility to a company that has just barely started to pull in revenue.&#160;</p><p>Read on below for our investigation of the SPAC craze, and for plenty of other news from the world of transportation. And if you haven't yet, <a href=\"http://newsletter.businessinsider.com/join/4np/shiftinggears\">sign up here to get this newsletter in your inbox every week</a>.</p><h2>Delta, American, and United ditch change fees</h2><p>Up in the air, the pain for airlines continues. President Trump has promised more aid for the industry, but without any tangible progress on that front, carriers are slashing their work forces —&#160;United this week announced plans to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/united-airlines-will-furlough-16370-employees-come-october-2020-9\">furlough more than 16,000 employees</a>. And with travel demand still depressed, it tried a fresh tactic: <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/united-airlines-ends-most-ticket-change-fees-not-basic-economy-2020-8\">dropping fees for passengers</a> who want to change flights after booking. Within 24 hours, Delta and American <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/the-big-3-us-airlines-drop-change-ancillary-fees-passengers-2020-8\">did the same</a>.&#160;</p><h2>EV startups cash in on Wall Street's 'blank check' IPO craze</h2><p>Senior reporter Mark Matousek offers a full breakdown of how reverse mergers work, what SPACs are, and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nikola-fisker-canoo-rejecting-method-tesla-uber-ipo-2020-9\">why companies like Nikola, Fisker, and Canoo are forgoing the traditional IPO</a>. Plus, he looks at why experts think <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/rivian-lucid-motors-most-likely-go-public-nikola-fisker-2020-8\">Rivian and Lucid Motors are the most likely to go next</a>.&#160;</p><h2>The EV startups most likely to become the next Tesla</h2><p>Many EV startups, one goal: follow Elon Musk's path from industry pest to industry giant by winning zillions of fans and building an outrageous valuation. Mark asked eight venture capitalists to name the EV makers they think have the most potential — <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/vcs-electric-vehicle-startups-revolutionize-car-industry-2020-8\">here are the top 11</a>.&#160;</p><h2>Everything else:&#160;</h2><ul><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/musk-promises-tesla-design-overhaul-ravecave-at-berlin-plant-2020-9\">Elon Musk says Tesla is radically overhauling its manufacturing process in Germany, where its factory will feature a 'ravecave'</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/el-al-israel-airlines-flies-first-flight-to-uae-peace-2020-9\">El Al just flew the first flight between Israel and the UAE as the two countries normalize relations – here's what it was like onboard</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/10-used-cars-largest-price-decrease-2020-9\">These 10 used cars are getting cheaper despite prices increasing this summer overall</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/2021-mercedes-benz-s-class-sedan-debut-specs-horsepower-dealerships-2020-9\">Mercedes' most executive sedan just got a huge makeover, with more luxury and screens than ever — check out the new S-Class</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mini-cooper-electric-beats-the-tesla-model-3-single-area-2020-8\">The Mini Cooper Electric beats the Tesla Model 3 on just one point — but it's a crucial one</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/contactless-cublicle-bathroom-handsfree-invention-latch-doorknob-innovation-tech-flight-2020-8\">This Japanese airline is the first to test an 'elbow-activated' toilet door amid health-related travel concerns</a></li></ul><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/1dT8qvRZIcA\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 15:29:54 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f5254d07ed0ee001e25d847?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"2110345f716556b85edeb738e14b3c9b","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn27@2020_3/2020/09/04/16-37-51-546_79e7a85228d65c0f.webp","destWidth":1778,"destHeight":1333,"sourceBytes":93336,"destBytes":93336,"author":"adavies@businessinsider.com (Alex Davies)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f525036e6ff30001d4e718b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn8@2020_4/2020/09/04/16-38-02-126_19e6592051a1cf35.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn3@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-38-03-978_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=1dT8qvRZIcA:kdpf7LUGecc:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn99@2020_2/2020/09/04/16-37-57-353_a96276a303da8fb6.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=1dT8qvRZIcA:kdpf7LUGecc:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn9@2020_4/2020/09/04/16-38-06-467_f1dd69fc419e8fd9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn24@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-37-59-085_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=1dT8qvRZIcA:kdpf7LUGecc:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn91@2020_5/2020/09/04/16-37-57-152_a7760409ac7e89bb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/1dT8qvRZIcA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn12@2020_2/2020/09/04/16-37-57-681_bcdc169d72eab4a4.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599237433616},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","title":"15 email etiquette rules every professional should know","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/email-etiquette-rules-every-professional-needs-to-know-2016-1","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f2b0fa57924a113b7131174?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Woman searching email on laptop\" height=\"1799\" width=\"2399\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Be cautious with humor when you write a work email.\n<p class=\"copyright\">mimagephotography/Shutterstock</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li><strong style=\"background-color: #ffffff;\">For many professionals, responding to emails takes up a <a href=\"https://cmo.adobe.com/articles/2019/9/if-you-think-email-is-dead--think-again.html#gs.q4gakd\">sizable chunk of work time</a>.&#160;</strong></li>\n<li><strong style=\"background-color: #ffffff;\">As millions of employees log in from home and correspond via email during the coronavirus pandemic, knowing how to be professional online is more important than ever.&#160;</strong></li>\n<li>While writing an email seems simple enough, there are mistakes many employees make when sending or receiving work messages.</li>\n<li>From avoiding the \"reply all\" button to double-checking for errors, here are 15 email etiquette tips every professional should know.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.</a></li>\n</ul><p>&#160;</p><p>Whether we like it or not, responding to emails consumes much of our time on the job. And amid the coronavirus pandemic, when millions of workers are working from home and corresponding by email, it's probably taking up even up more time than usual.&#160;</p><p>Since more Americans began working from home amid the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-long-burn-not-seasonal-waves-2020-7\">coronavirus pandemic</a>, workers are sending out more emails and spending more time at work, per the <a href=\"https://www.nber.org/papers/w27612.pdf?utm_source=morning_brew\">National Bureau of Economic Research</a>.</p><p>Despite the fact that we're sending so many emails, <a href=\"http://www.pachter.com/\">career coach Barbara Pachter</a> said plenty of professionals still don't know how to write them properly.</p><p>Because of the sheer volume of messages we're reading and writing, we may be more prone to making embarrassing errors, and those mistakes can have serious consequences.</p><p>Pachter outlines the basics of modern email etiquette in her book \"<a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/The-Essentials-Business-Etiquette-Success/dp/0071811265\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">The Essentials of Business Etiquette</a>.\" We pulled out the most essential rules you need to know.</p><p><em>Jacquelyn Smith, Caroline Hroncich, Vivian Giang, and Rachel Sugar contributed to earlier versions of this article.</em></p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tInclude a clear, direct subject line.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dfd448a855cc240c338171b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"laptop working finances\" height=\"999\" width=\"1332\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>People decide if they want to read your email just based on the subject line.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Maskot/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Examples of a good subject line include \"Meeting date changed,\" \"Quick question about your presentation,\" or \"Suggestions for the proposal.\"</p><p>\"People often decide whether to open an email based on the subject line,\" Pachter said. \"Choose one that lets readers know you are addressing their concerns or business issues.\"</p>\n\tUse a professional email address.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5d8b8d832e22af33af79dff8?format=jpeg\" alt=\"person working on computer\" height=\"5269\" width=\"7026\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Never use email addresses that are not appropriate for use in the workplace.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Courtesy of eclipse_images/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>If you work for a company, you should use your company email address. But if you use a personal email account &#8212; whether you are self-employed or just like using it occasionally for work-related correspondences &#8212; you should be careful when choosing that address, Pachter said.</p><p>You should always have an email address that conveys your name so that the recipient knows exactly who is sending the email. Never use email addresses (perhaps remnants of your grade-school days) that are not appropriate for use in the workplace, such as \"babygirl@...\" or \"beerlover@...\" &#8212; no matter how much you love a cold brew.</p>\n\tThink twice before hitting 'reply all.'\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/54073c8169bedd893e5326f0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"laptops\" height=\"1990\" width=\"2654\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Refrain from hitting reply all.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Reuters/Lucas Jackson</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>No one wants to read emails from 20 people that have nothing to do with them. Ignoring the emails can be difficult, with many workers getting notifications of new messages on their smartphones or distracting pop-up messages on their computer screens. Refrain from hitting \"reply all\" unless you really think everyone on the list needs to receive the email, Pachter said.</p>\n\tInclude a signature block.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/56af93d5c08a80880e8be12c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"email\" height=\"611\" width=\"815\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Provide the reader with helpful information about you.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jacquelyn Smith/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Provide<strong>&#160;</strong>your reader with some information about you, Pachter suggested. \"Generally, this would state your full name, title, the company name, and your contact information, including a phone number. You also can add a little publicity for yourself, but don't go overboard with any sayings or artwork.\"</p><p>Use the same font, type size, and color as the rest of the email, she said.</p><p>&#160;</p>\n\tUse professional salutations.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5cc20937b14bf46766013136?format=jpeg\" alt=\"high five\" height=\"3414\" width=\"4552\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Don&#39;t use laid back expressions.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Caiaimage/Paul Bradbury / Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Don't use laid-back, colloquial expressions like, \"Hey you guys,\" \"Yo,\" or \"Hi folks.\"</p><p>\"The relaxed nature of our writings should not affect the salutation in an email,\" she said. \"<em>Hey</em> is a very informal salutation and generally it should not be used in the workplace. And <em>Yo</em> is not OK either. Use <em>Hi</em> or <em>Hello</em> instead.\"</p><p>She also advises against shortening anyone's name. Say \"Hi Michael,\" unless you're certain he prefers to be called \"Mike.\"</p>\n\tUse exclamation points sparingly.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5a6a0dfecf84101c008b46fa?format=jpeg\" alt=\"woman computer laptop working\" height=\"667\" width=\"889\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Don&#39;t use more than one exclamation point.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Lazarenko Svetlana/Shutterstock</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>If you choose to use an exclamation point, use only one to convey excitement, Pachter said.</p><p>\"People sometimes get carried away and put a number of exclamation points at the end of their sentences. The result can appear too emotional or immature,\" she wrote. \"Exclamation points should be used sparingly in writing.\"&#160;</p>\n\tBe cautious with humor.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5d5d2aaccd978412d40162a2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"laughing at work\" height=\"766\" width=\"1021\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Try to avoid humor in professional emails.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Humor can easily get lost in translation without the right tone or facial expressions. In a professional exchange, it's better to leave humor out of emails unless you know the recipient well. Also, something that you think is funny might not be funny to someone else.</p><p>Pachter said: \"Something perceived as funny when spoken may come across very differently when written. When in doubt, leave it out.\"</p>\n\tKnow that people from different cultures speak and write differently.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/56af8eaa58c3231a008b6dbc?format=jpeg\" alt=\"globe world earth\" height=\"1498\" width=\"1997\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Miscommunication may occur because of cultural differences.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Kieran Doherty/Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Miscommunication can easily occur because of <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/etiquette-differences-between-japan-and-us-2018-6\">cultural differences</a>, especially in the writing form when we can't see one another's body language. Tailor your message to the receiver's cultural background or how well you know them.</p><p>A good rule to keep in mind, Pachter said, is that high-context cultures (Japanese, Arab, or Chinese) want to get to know you before doing business with you. Therefore, it may be common for business associates from these countries to be more personal in their writings. On the other hand, people from low-context cultures (German, American, or Scandinavia) prefer to get to the point very quickly.</p>\n\tReply to your emails — even if the email wasn't intended for you.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/540738e66bb3f75c29fded30?format=jpeg\" alt=\"laptop guy working\" height=\"1779\" width=\"2372\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Try to respond to all of the emails you receive.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Adam Berry/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>It's difficult to reply to every email message ever sent to you, but you should try to, Pachter said. This includes when the email was accidentally sent to you, especially if the sender is expecting a reply. A reply isn't necessary but serves as good email etiquette, especially if this person works in the same company or industry as you.</p><p>Here's an example reply: \"I know you're very&#160;busy, but I don't think you meant to send this email to me. And I&#160;wanted to let you know so you can send it to the correct person.\"</p>\n\tProofread every message.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5a14a5233dbef4cf008b79c6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"woman looking at computer screen\" height=\"3115\" width=\"4153\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Don&#39;t just rely on spell check.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Francois Mori/AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Your mistakes won't go unnoticed by the recipients of your email. \"And, depending upon the recipient, you may be judged for making them,\" Pachter said.</p><p>Don't rely on spell-check. Read and reread your email a few times, preferably aloud, before sending it off.</p><p>\"One supervisor intended to write 'Sorry for the inconvenience,'\" Pachter said. \"But he relied on his spell-check and ended up writing 'Sorry for the incontinence.'\"</p>\n\tAdd the email address last.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5c9e3819c6cc502b272d6613?format=jpeg\" alt=\"meaningful work woman looking at computer\" height=\"1414\" width=\"1885\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>This can help avoid accidentally sending an email before you have finished writing.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.gettyimages.com/detail/photo/concentrated-african-american-woman-brainstorming-royalty-free-image/956379138\" target=\"_blank\">skynesher/Getty Images</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>\"You don't want to send an email accidentally before you have finished writing and proofing the message,\" Pachter said. \"Even when you are replying to a message, it's a good precaution to delete the recipient's address and insert it only when you are sure the message is ready to be sent.\"</p>\n\tDouble-check that you've selected the correct recipient.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e138aa9855cc274721affa2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"embarrassed\" height=\"800\" width=\"1067\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Pay close attention to who your emailing.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Giulio_Fornasar/Shutterstock</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Pachter said to pay careful attention when typing a name from your address book on the email's \"To\" line. \"It's easy to select the wrong name, which can be embarrassing to you and to the person who receives the email by mistake.\"</p>\n\tKeep your fonts classic.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5d49e3a3100a2415d5584b23?format=jpeg\" alt=\"frustrated man computer not working\" height=\"2000\" width=\"2667\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Make sure your email is easy to read.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Shutterstock</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Purple Comic Sans has a time and a place (maybe?) but for business correspondence, keep your fonts, colors, and sizes classic.</p><p>The cardinal rule: Your emails should be easy for other people to read.</p><p>\"Generally, it is best to use 10- or 12-point type and an easy-to-read font such as Arial, Calibri, or Times New Roman,\" Pachter advised. As for color, black is the safest choice.</p>\n\tKeep tabs on your tone.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5aea2a3519ee8624008b47db?format=jpeg\" alt=\"typing at computer woman laptop working\" height=\"1335\" width=\"1780\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Say please and thank you.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.shutterstock.com/g/daxiao\" target=\"_blank\">Daxiao Productions/Shutterstock</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Just as jokes get lost in translation, tone is easy to misconstrue without the context you'd get from vocal cues and facial expressions. Accordingly, it's easy to come off as more abrupt that you might have intended. You meant \"straightforward\"; they read \"angry and curt.\"</p><p>To avoid misunderstandings, Pachter recommended you read your message out loud before hitting send. \"If it sounds harsh to you, it will sound harsh to the reader,\" she said.</p><p>For best results, avoid using unequivocally negative words (\"failure,\" \"wrong,\" or \"neglected\"), and always say \"please\" and \"thank you.\"</p>\n\tNothing is confidential — so write accordingly.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/58adbbf401fe580f018b5fac?format=jpeg\" alt=\"eyestrain stressed tired computer working\" height=\"1602\" width=\"2136\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Assume others will see what you write.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dean Drobot/Shutterstock</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Always remember what former former CIA Director David Petraeus apparently forgot, warns Pachter: <em>Every</em> electronic message leaves a trail.</p><p>\"A basic guideline is to assume that others will see what you write,\" she said. \"So don't write anything you wouldn't want everyone to see.\" A more liberal interpretation: Don't write anything that would be ruinous to you or hurtful to others. After all, email is dangerously easy to forward, and it's better to be safe than sorry.</p>\n</div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/email-etiquette-rules-every-professional-needs-to-know-2016-1'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a 2020 13:56:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f2b10ed24381710b739b574?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"b1508cc05d7b31fa58d9cf5a27a4607c","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn78@2020_4/2020/09/04/16-37-34-217_cc33981633577e75.webp","destWidth":1885,"destHeight":1414,"sourceBytes":87400,"destBytes":87400,"author":"insider@insider.com (Allana Akhtar,Marguerite Ward)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f2b0fa57924a113b7131174?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn47@2020_3/2020/09/04/16-38-06-457_d580a62b30227c1c.webp","https://i.insider.com/5dfd448a855cc240c338171b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn40@2020_3/2020/09/04/16-37-34-293_3f0bc712e3d4cd32.webp","https://i.insider.com/5d8b8d832e22af33af79dff8?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn15@2020_5/2020/09/04/16-37-48-358_5336ddf74172deff.webp","https://i.insider.com/54073c8169bedd893e5326f0?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn91@2020_5/2020/09/04/16-37-55-588_d21cd15b126968c1.webp","https://i.insider.com/56af93d5c08a80880e8be12c?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn35@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-37-59-267_7ca1353acbb7205f.webp","https://i.insider.com/5cc20937b14bf46766013136?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn27@2020_3/2020/09/04/16-37-57-754_de42acfcc5014221.webp","https://i.insider.com/5a6a0dfecf84101c008b46fa?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn28@2020_2/2020/09/04/16-38-05-916_90eff2b81b96384a.webp","https://i.insider.com/5d5d2aaccd978412d40162a2?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn61@2020_5/2020/09/04/16-38-05-213_a75bc2b510100e7f.webp","https://i.insider.com/56af8eaa58c3231a008b6dbc?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn75@2020_4/2020/09/04/16-38-06-144_962da930f6806e7d.webp","https://i.insider.com/540738e66bb3f75c29fded30?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn44@2020_2/2020/09/04/16-38-04-012_715f588b8531dfdb.webp","https://i.insider.com/5a14a5233dbef4cf008b79c6?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn11@2020_2/2020/09/04/16-38-04-033_49f0ade0f937ab6d.webp","https://i.insider.com/5c9e3819c6cc502b272d6613?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn95@2020_4/2020/09/04/16-38-00-888_13991b8376f777d9.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e138aa9855cc274721affa2?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_2/2020/09/04/16-38-07-410_4d75a33cbfc5995e.webp","https://i.insider.com/5d49e3a3100a2415d5584b23?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn20@2020_5/2020/09/04/16-38-01-356_797d9b9a718e5b0a.webp","https://i.insider.com/5aea2a3519ee8624008b47db?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn63@2020_3/2020/09/04/16-38-01-978_fd1c029e3acab824.webp","https://i.insider.com/58adbbf401fe580f018b5fac?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn36@2020_5/2020/09/04/16-38-07-298_5a3625a8e250eb13.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn3@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-38-03-978_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=QvgI5j5ey-w:L5rVliAAvp0:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn23@2020_5/2020/09/04/16-37-50-422_2f5414008c4d6cc0.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=QvgI5j5ey-w:L5rVliAAvp0:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn64@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-37-56-727_c339ff9658d2c2e9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn24@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-37-59-085_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=QvgI5j5ey-w:L5rVliAAvp0:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn44@2020_4/2020/09/04/16-38-06-613_f85958a73b06b962.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/QvgI5j5ey-w":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn80@2020_3/2020/09/04/16-38-03-487_b2ff56987da3eea5.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599237433647},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","title":"'The Umbrella Academy' has become Netflix's biggest hit series since 'The Witcher'","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/umbrella-academy-season-2-biggest-netflix-hit-since-the-witcher-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f22ca7e3ad8616ba336d3aa?format=jpeg\" alt=\"the umbrella academy\" height=\"1382\" width=\"2352\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>&#34;The Umbrella Academy&#34; season two.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Netflix</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Netflix's \"The Umbrella Academy\" on Thursday topped Nielsen's first list of top streaming TV shows, with more than 3 billion minutes watched during the week of August 3-9.</li>\n<li>It's the latest data point to indicate that the series has surged in popularity since season two debuted on July 31, and it's become clear this new season has made it the most popular Netflix original since \"The Witcher.\"</li>\n<li>\"The Umbrella Academy\" is still among Netflix's own daily lists of its most popular titles, and Parrot Analytics considers it the most in-demand original streaming series in the US.</li>\n<li>Reviews for season two have been stellar, with a 90% Rotten Tomatoes critic score compared with season one's 75%.</li>\n<li>A few factors could be contributing to the show's surge in popularity, with people more likely to be home watching TV during the coronavirus pandemic and with sci-fi and fantasy shows continuing to dominate streaming.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Netflix's comic-book series \"The Umbrella Academy\" was a hit last year when its first season debuted. But the show seems to have expanded its audience even further with <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/netflix-umbrella-academy-season-2-interview-budget-future-plans-2020-7\">season two, which dropped July 31</a>.</p><p>On Thursday, Nielsen released its <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nielsen-data-shows-value-netflix-library-of-old-tv-shows-2020-9\">first list of top streaming shows in the US</a> from the platforms it measures, which for now include only Netflix and Amazon Prime Video. Netflix dominated with acquired series like \"The Office\" and \"Grey's Anatomy.\"&#160;</p><p>\"The Umbrella Academy\" was the lone Netflix original on the list, but it topped everything else by a long shot with more than 3 billion minutes watched over the week of August 3-9. Users spent 1.1 billion minutes watching the No. 2 show, \"Shameless,\" and 918 million minutes watching the No. 3 show, \"Grey's Anatomy,\" during the same time period.</p><p>It's the latest data point indicating that \"The Umbrella Academy\" is a monster hit, and it's become clear that the new season has made this the most popular Netflix original since \"<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/netflix-the-witcher-still-biggest-show-worldwide-sci-fi-fantasy-2020-2#:~:text=Netflix's%20hit%20fantasy%20series%2C%20%22The,worldwide%20for%20nearly%20two%20months.\">The Witcher</a>,\" which debuted in December. Netflix said \"The Witcher\" was its <a href=\"https://variety.com/2019/tv/news/netflix-most-popular-tv-series-2019-stranger-things-the-witcher-when-they-see-us-1203453295/\">second-biggest series of 2019</a>, behind \"Stranger Things\" season three. The third-biggest series? \"The Umbrella Academy\" season one.</p><p>Based on the numbers, season two seems to be even bigger. Beyond Nielsen, the series shot straight to the top of Netflix's own daily lists of its most popular titles in the US after season two debuted, and it is still among the top 10 more than a month later (Netflix <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-netflix-calculates-its-new-daily-top-10-lists-2020-2\">counts a view if an account watches at least two minutes</a> of a show and bases the lists on the previous 24 hours).</p><p>The data firm Parrot Analytics says \"The Umbrella Academy\" has also been <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/top-streaming-tv-shows-week-netflix-cobra-kai-umbrella-academy-2020-9\">the most in-demand original streaming series in the US</a> since season two premiered. The company measures \"demand expressions,\" which account for the desire, engagement, and viewership of a given show. On Friday, the series <a href=\"https://tv.parrotanalytics.com/US/the-umbrella-academy-netflix\">was 103 times as in demand</a> as the average TV series in the US in the past 30 days.</p><p>So why has the series surged in popularity this year?</p><p>Streaming in general <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/disney-plus-hulu-getting-biggest-subscriber-gains-surveys-2020-4\">has seen a rise during the coronavirus</a> pandemic, as people have stayed home to practice social distancing. And the reviews have been stellar, with season two gaining an impressive 90% critic score on Rotten Tomatoes compared with season one's 75%.&#160;</p><p>\"If last season spent too long waiting to get to the fireworks factory, this season opens on that factory and only promises to get more explosive from there,\" Caroline Siede wrote for <a href=\"https://tv.avclub.com/in-its-season-two-premiere-the-umbrella-academy-reinve-1844521689\">AV Club</a>.</p><p>It also has an advantage being a sci-fi/fantasy series, which is <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-makes-a-streaming-tv-series-a-hit-witcher-mandalorian-2020-1\">regularly the dominant genre</a> on Parrot Analytics' weekly lists of most in-demand streaming originals. These shows, whether \"The Umbrella Academy\" or \"The Witcher\" or Disney Plus' \"Star Wars\" series \"The Mandalorian,\" are often inspired by source material. From a demand standpoint, that begs more engagement.</p><p>\"When you think about the demand expression number, what's going into that is not just the consumption, but also the social aspect of it and the research aspect of it,\" Courtney Williams, Parrot Analytics' head of partnerships,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/the-streaming-battle-between-witcher-and-mandalorian-explained-2020-1\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"7aca7f200e43f243aa7811cf9fb6218c\">told Business Insider</a> in January.</p><p>Ultimately, \"The Umbrella Academy\" season one was <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com.au/netflix-renews-the-umbrella-academy-for-season-2-details-2019-4\">watched by 45 million member households</a> globally in its first month, Netflix said. We'll probably find out how many people watched season two in its first month when Netflix reports its third-quarter earnings.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/umbrella-academy-season-2-biggest-netflix-hit-since-the-witcher-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a
