border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/YHUuKHZLMlk\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 15:35:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f3fb27c42f43f001ddfe3c2?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"70881be8350bf6bafd73a378f7d7a07f","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn57@2020_4/2020/09/04/16-37-34-207_faeef2ced2875ea5.webp","destWidth":2266,"destHeight":1700,"sourceBytes":170612,"destBytes":170612,"author":"tmohamed@businessinsider.com (Theron Mohamed)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f52156d7ed0ee001e25d746?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn68@2020_4/2020/09/04/16-37-55-335_1c64853659f0330a.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f525c3ce6ff30001d4e71e2?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn32@2020_2/2020/09/04/16-38-04-897_38403a1b0fb6bad2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn3@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-38-03-978_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=YHUuKHZLMlk:7FjDNIKDJpk:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn32@2020_4/2020/09/04/16-38-02-355_f6867132a9656acf.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=YHUuKHZLMlk:7FjDNIKDJpk:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn71@2020_3/2020/09/04/16-38-04-592_32fa7eba4a7284c5.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn24@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-37-59-085_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=YHUuKHZLMlk:7FjDNIKDJpk:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn15@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-37-59-233_d45056ecea78c505.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/YHUuKHZLMlk":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn83@2020_3/2020/09/04/16-38-02-931_6fc50a8f3f66192e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599237433600},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","title":"The Pentagon is moving to shut down its independent newspaper Stars and Stripes, but a bipartisan group of senators are mounting a last-ditch effort to save it","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/lawmakers-mount-last-ditch-effort-to-save-stars-and-stripes-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f5263fee6ff30001d4e7224?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Command Sgt. Maj. Robert Sweeney, the command sergeant major for the 81st Brigade Combat Team, Washington Army National Guard, reads a quote from &#39;Stars and Stripes&#39; to Chief Warrant Officer David Dean and 1st Sgt. Charles Lia, both with 81st BCT, during the Camp Ramadi Softball League championship game on Camp Ramadi, Iraq, April 25, 2009.\" height=\"500\" width=\"1000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Command Sgt. Maj. Robert Sweeney, the command sergeant major for the 81st Brigade Combat Team, Washington Army National Guard, reads a quote from &#39;Stars and Stripes&#39; to Chief Warrant Officer David Dean and 1st Sgt. Charles Lia, both with 81st BCT, during the Camp Ramadi Softball League championship game on Camp Ramadi, Iraq, April 25, 2009.\n<p class=\"copyright\">US Army photo</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The Pentagon is pushing ahead with plans to scrap Stars and Stripes, its indepedent newspaper, but lawmakers are fighting to save it.</li>\n<li>Stars and Stripes was first published during the Civil War, and it has been published regularly since World War II.</li>\n<li>The Department of Defense first announced plans to pull the paper's $15.5 million in funding in February. If moves to save the paper are unsuccessful, publication could cease on Sept. 30.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The Department of Defense is pushing ahead with plans to shutter Stars and Stripes, the US military's independent newspaper, but a bipartisan group of lawmakers are fighting to save it.</p><p><a href=\"https://twitter.com/nikkiwentling/status/1301196791082254336\">Fifteen senators wrote a letter to Secretary of Defense Mark Esper on Wednesday expressing concern</a> about the Department of Defense's plan to scrap the paper.</p><p>Noting that the $15.5 million required to fund Stars and Stripes is only a fraction of the Pentagon budget of more than $700 billion, they argued that \"cutting it would have a significantly negative impact on military families and a negligible impact on the Department's bottom line.\"</p><p><a href=\"https://www.stripes.com/about#branches1-1\">According to Stars and Stripes</a>, the newspaper, which is now published in print and available online, is \"editorially independent of interference from outside its own editorial chain-of-command\" and provides \"independent news and information to the US military community, including active-duty servicemembers, DoD civilians, veterans, contractors, and their families.\"</p><p>Much of the annual budget, <a href=\"https://www.stripes.com/news/us/bipartisan-group-of-senators-urges-esper-to-keep-funding-stars-and-stripes-1.643650?fbclid=IwAR3AiT60HIJ7kcDA0WlFTekYmgaJ2h4bN739WQjfKaICSPnDqeyyhOXs1go#.X1ACLVlJbdU.twitter\">according to the military paper</a>, is used to distribute newspapers to troops in places around the world, including conflict zones.</p><p>Esper decided that Stars and Stripes was no longer necessary after a review of Pentagon spending, and Elaine McCusker, then the Pentagon's acting comptroller, explained in February that funding for the paper would be cut because the department had decided that \"newspapers are probably not the best way that we communicate any longer.\"</p><p>The first newspaper with the name Stars and Stripes was published during the Civil War on Nov. 9, 1861 by Union troops.</p><p>In the letter written Wednesday, the concerned senators argued that \"Stars and Stripes is a historically significant publication in our country,\" explaining that \"it originated during the Civil War and has been published continuously since World War II.\"</p><p>In the letter, the senators said that the plan was to suspend publication on Sept. 30, 2020 and dissolve the newspaper by Jan. 31, 2020. <a href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/opinion/2020/09/04/trump-and-stars-and-stripes-attacking-american-icon-column/5706859002/\">A USA Today op-ed published Friday suggests</a> that the Pentagon has accelerated the timetable.</p><p>A Pentagon memo reportedly presents a plan that \"dissolves the Stars and Stripes\" by Sept. 15 and includes specific plans for the vacating of government-owned/leased spaces. \"The last newspaper publication (in all forms) will be September 30, 2020,\" the memo written by Col. Paul Haverstick Jr., the Defense Media Activity director, reportedly states.</p><p>As the paper is an important news source for US service members, including those on deployment, and veterans and military families, the 15 senators wrote Wednesday that \"Stars and Stripes is an essential part of our nation's freedom of the press that serves the very population charged with defending that freedom.\"</p><p>\"Therefore, we respectfully request that you rescind your decision to discontinue support for Stars and Stripes and that you reinstate the funding necessary for it to continue operations,\" they wrote.</p><p>The senators urged the secretary of defense to prevent disruptions to the paper, explaining that there is a \"real possibility\" that Congress will choose to continue funding the paper.</p><p>But, it is currently unclear if Congress, which has struggled to approve a budget in a timely manner, will be able to intervene before the Pentagon shuts down the paper's operations.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/lawmakers-mount-last-ditch-effort-to-save-stars-and-stripes-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=GdNhXmcT4gM:HjNtN3rrR0g:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=GdNhXmcT4gM:HjNtN3rrR0g:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=GdNhXmcT4gM:HjNtN3rrR0g:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=GdNhXmcT4gM:HjNtN3rrR0g:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=GdNhXmcT4gM:HjNtN3rrR0g:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=GdNhXmcT4gM:HjNtN3rrR0g:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=GdNhXmcT4gM:HjNtN3rrR0g:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=GdNhXmcT4gM:HjNtN3rrR0g:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/GdNhXmcT4gM\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 15:35:43 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f526406e6ff30001d4e7225?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"7b6f0da37dbd371388c6b8ee661c95fe","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn53@2020_4/2020/09/04/16-37-46-225_409290876f189c7d.webp","destWidth":885,"destHeight":664,"sourceBytes":38064,"destBytes":38064,"author":"rpickrell@businessinsider.com (Ryan Pickrell)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f5263fee6ff30001d4e7224?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn79@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-38-02-766_0c1f7e8645529c64.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn3@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-38-03-978_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=GdNhXmcT4gM:HjNtN3rrR0g:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn51@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-38-03-475_9b205e6ca1cf179a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=GdNhXmcT4gM:HjNtN3rrR0g:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn71@2020_4/2020/09/04/16-38-01-331_6f71fc8b0d4d4b84.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn24@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-37-59-085_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=GdNhXmcT4gM:HjNtN3rrR0g:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn88@2020_3/2020/09/04/16-38-07-128_8cb179b394521045.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/GdNhXmcT4gM":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn71@2020_2/2020/09/04/16-37-55-448_a7f518bed7758bc6.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599237433598},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","title":"Steroids can seriously reduce risk of death from COVID-19, new trials show. The WHO is strongly recommending them.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/steroids-may-help-covid-19-patients-survive-research-shows-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ee93e725af6cc1a360a2e52?format=jpeg\" alt=\"A pharmacist displays a box of Dexamethasone at the Erasme Hospital amid the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, in Brussels, Belgium, June 16, 2020. REUTERS/Yves Herman\" height=\"3480\" width=\"5298\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A pharmacist displays a box of Dexamethasone at the Erasme Hospital amid the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, in Brussels, Germany.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Corticosteroids are a class of drugs that suppress out-of-control immune-system responses.</li>\n<li>They may improve survival rates for patients with severe cases of COVID-19, according to new research.</li>\n<li>Based on the results of seven clinical trials, the World Health Organization issued a \"strong recommendation\" for the use of steroids among seriously ill patients.&#160;</li>\n<li>Steroids are cheaper and more readily available than remdesivir, the only other drug that's shown promise in treating serious COVID-19 cases.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>&#160;</p><p>Corticosteroids — a cheap and widely available class of drugs — can help people with serious cases of COVID-19 survive, according to trial results published this week.&#160;</p><p><a href=\"https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2770279\">A robust analysis</a> looking at seven trials of corticosteroids found that when patients on ventilators were treated with steroids, they had a 30% chance of dying, compared with a 38% chance among patients who didn't take steroids. For patients treated without ventilators, the benefit was even greater: People given steroids had a 23% chance of dying, compared with a 42% chance for people in a control group.&#160;</p><p>\"This is equivalent to around 68% of [the sickest] patients surviving after treatment with corticosteroids, compared to around 60% surviving in the absence of corticosteroids,\" the researchers said, <a href=\"https://reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-steroids/steroids-cut-death-rates-among-critically-ill-covid-19-patients-major-study-finds-idUSKBN25T20D\">according to Reuters</a>.</p><p>The steroids in the trials included methylprednisolone, hydrocortisone and dexamethasone.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f07363d3ad86122b61c2638?format=jpeg\" alt=\"FILE PHOTO: A logo is pictured on the World Health Organization (WHO) headquarters in Geneva, Switzerland, November 22, 2017.  REUTERS/Denis Balibouse\" height=\"3000\" width=\"4448\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A logo is pictured on the World Health Organization headquarters in Geneva, Switzerland.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Based on the results, the World Health Organization issued a <a href=\"https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/WHO-2019-nCoV-Corticosteroids-2020.1\">\"strong recommendation\"</a> on Wednesday that doctors give seriously ill COVID-19 patients dexamethasone or hydrocortisone. The organization isn't recommending steroids for people who are not seriously ill, however.&#160;&#160;</p><h2><strong>Corticosteroids can prevent immune-system overreactions</strong></h2><p>Corticosteroids are synthetic hormones that mimic cortisol, a hormone the body produces naturally to help regulate metabolism, immune reactions, and stress response. Doctors use corticosteroids to tamp down on overactive immune systems and reduce inflammation, which can help with a variety of conditions including asthma and skin disorders.</p><p>The coronavirus can trigger overactive immune responses, which can be deadly: When too many white blood cells <a href=\"https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2020/05/200513081810.htm\">flood the bloodstream</a>, some attack healthy tissue in addition to the virus. Steroids, then, can help suppress that kind of dangerous immune response among COVID-19 patients.&#160;</p><p>Scientists at Oxford University found in June that dexamethasone, specifically, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/dexamethasone-steroid-touted-as-coronavirus-breakthrough-drug-risky-mild-cases-2020-6\">improves patients' survival rates</a>, but at that time, experts and international organizations wanted more evidence before making recommendations. Now they have it.</p><p>\"Clearly, now steroids are the standard of care,\" Dr. Howard C. Bauchner, the editor-in-chief of the Journal of the American Medical Association, <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/02/health/coronavirus-steroids.html\">told The New York Times</a>.</p><h2><strong>Corticosteroids are cheaper than remdesivir and </strong><strong>may be more effective</strong></h2><p>Remdesivir is the only other drug so far that rigorous trials have found to be effective for treating seriously ill COVID-19 patients. In May, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-treatment-gilead-says-positive-data-remdesivir-from-niaid-study-2020-4\">a study found</a> that remdesivir shortened recovery times for those patients. However, a recent study also found that patients on a 10-day course of remdesivir <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/remdesivir-may-not-significantly-improve-covid-19-outcomes-study-2020-8\">died at about the same rates</a> as people given other treatments.</p><p>Corticosteroids, then, might offer more promise.</p><p>\"I had a big smile on my face when I saw the results,\" Dr. Derek C. Angus, chair of the department of critical care medicine at the University of Pittsburgh and a co-author of one of the trials, <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/02/health/coronavirus-steroids.html\">told the Times</a>.&#160;</p><p>The National Institutes of Health also now <a href=\"https://www.covid19treatmentguidelines.nih.gov/immune-based-therapy/immunomodulators/corticosteroids/\">recommends corticosteroids</a>, particularly dexamethasone, for COVID-19 patients who need ventilators or supplemental oxygen.&#160;</p><p>An added benefit of corticosteroids is that they're cheap. A six-to-10-day treatment course of dexamethasone would likely cost would cost most customers between $10 and $13, according to Michael Rea, the CEO of Rx Savings Solutions, which sells software designed to help select less expensive medicines.</p><p>By contrast, Gilead Sciences, the maker of remdesivir, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/remdesivir-may-not-significantly-improve-covid-19-outcomes-study-2020-8\">has said</a> it would charge governments of developed countries $2,340 for a five-day course of the drug.</p><h2>Steroids can have side effects, though</h2><p>Corticosteroids can have some side effects, particularly in elderly patients: The drugs can leave people vulnerable to other infections and raise the risk of high blood pressure, glaucoma, weight gain, and delirium.&#160;</p><p>They also don't appear to be effective for less serious cases. In the Oxford trial, for example, patients with mild cases who took dexamethasone <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/dexamethasone-steroid-touted-as-coronavirus-breakthrough-drug-risky-mild-cases-2020-6\">died at slightly higher rates</a> than those with mild cases who didn't take the drug.</p><p>That's why the WHO and the NIH aren't recommending steroids for patients who aren't severely sick. But for the most life-threatening cases, the pros appear to outweigh the cons.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/steroids-may-help-covid-19-patients-survive-research-shows-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=8xLTI2JCOAs:q16RdtwqcbA:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a Beach, California, in 2011.\n<p class=\"copyright\">J. Emilio Flores/Corbis via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul><li>&#160;</li><li><strong>Tesla falls another 4% following Thursday's 9% decline in which the <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/index/nasdaq_100?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestgest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Nasdaq-100</a> fell by more than 5%, its sharpest one-day drop since March.</strong></li><li><strong>Tesla's biggest shareholder, Scottish asset manager Baillie Gifford, was forced to trim its stake in the company due to new internal rules limiting the weight of certain stocks in portfolios this week.</strong></li><li><strong>Tesla's 5-for-1 stocks split came in effect on Monday and the company is looking to raise $5 billion in a share sale.&#160;</strong></li><li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</strong></li></ul><p>Shares in luxury electric vehicle maker and stock market favorite Tesla fell by as much as 5% in early trade on Wall Street on Friday, set for a fourth straight day of declines, the longest since the depths of the coronavirus crisis in mid-March.&#160;</p><p>It is was last down around 4% at $390.50 as of 10:15 am. ET, while the Nasdaq 100 was down 1.75% on the day, under pressure from government data that showed the US economy created fewer jobs than expected last month. The monthly non-farm payrolls report showed a rise of 1.371 million, just shy of a forecast for 1.4 million.</p><p>Tesla, which has risen by over 400% so far this year, fell by 9% on Thursday, alongside the FAANG stocks- <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/fb-stock?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestm=ingest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Facebook</a>,&#160;<a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/aapl-stock?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestm=ingest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Apple</a>,&#160;<a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/amzn-stock?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestm=ingest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Amazon</a>,&#160;<a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/nflx-stock?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestm=ingest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Netflix</a>, and Google parent&#160;<a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/goog-stock?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestm=ingest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Alphabet</a> - which tanked after rallying through the start of the month and enjoying historically expensive valuations.&#160;</p><p>As a result, the <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/index/nasdaq_100?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestgest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Nasdaq-100</a> experienced its sharpest one-day drop since March, with a drop of 5.2%. On Friday morning, the index was last down 1.6%, compared with a more modest 0.3% fall in the S&#38;P 500.&#160;</p><p><em data-stringify-type=\"italic\"><strong data-stringify-type=\"bold\">Read More:</strong>&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-invest-in-real-estate-after-coronavirus-tips-ubs-2020-9?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestgest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" data-stringify-link=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-invest-in-real-estate-after-coronavirus-tips-ubs-2020-9\" data-sk=\"tooltip_parent\">A UBS real estate-investing chief told us 5 ways investors can profit from the pandemic's transformation of how Americans live and work - including the housing markets poised to boom</a></em></p><p>It has been a volatile week for Tesla. Its shares <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/tesla-stock-price-largest-outside-investor-forced-trim-stake-rally-2020-9-1029557419?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest#est#\">fell 6% on Wednesday,</a> after Baillie Gifford, the company's largest shareholder, said it <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/teslas-largest-investor-ballie-gifford-trims-stake-after-stock-tear-2020-9?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestm=ingest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">had trimmed its stake in the company</a> because of internal rules constraining the weight of a single stock in client portfolios.</p><figure>\n\t<img href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/tesla-stock-price-share-split-announcement-affordable-electric-investor-retail-2020-8-1029496869?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest#est#\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">&#160;5-for-1 stocks split went into effect on Monday</a>, and on Tuesday the company announced plans to raise up to&#160; <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/tesla-stock-price-share-sale-5-billion-record-setting-surge-2020-9-1029552948?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest#est#\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">$5 billion in a share sale.</a></p><p><strong data-stringify-type=\"bold\"><em data-stringify-type=\"italic\">Read More:&#160;</em></strong><em data-stringify-type=\"italic\"><a down how the company's $5 billion stock sale could benefit retail investors - and explains why the electric-car giant would still be cheap at $1,400 per share in 2024</a></em></p><p>Many market watchers think tech stocks have risen too aggressively, and a correction was inevitable, but most are still bullish on the outlook for Tesla stock.</p><p><a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=sQvyn1T_00o:YC0hKHIW-Zs:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=sQvyn1T_00o:YC0hKHIW-Zs:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=sQvyn1T_00o:YC0hKHIW-Zs:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=sQvyn1T_00o:YC0hKHIW-Zs:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/sQvyn1T_00o\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 14:18:33 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f5233c3e6ff30001d4e70e3?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"5782ed674704fb3e2b46316a5747b615","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn97@2020_5/2020/09/04/16-37-34-333_10be8728e13c8dca.webp","destWidth":2488,"destHeight":1866,"sourceBytes":106978,"destBytes":106978,"author":"insider@insider.com (Saloni Sardana)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f5233947ed0ee001e25d778?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn71@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-37-58-438_bfd914dfa80440ac.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f523ee3e6ff30001d4e70fe?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn7@2020_5/2020/09/04/16-38-07-264_0469ab90a02b2cd3.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn3@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-38-03-978_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=sQvyn1T_00o:YC0hKHIW-Zs:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn48@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-37-56-602_57dab864363bbc83.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=sQvyn1T_00o:YC0hKHIW-Zs:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn91@2020_3/2020/09/04/16-38-02-143_37fa82d3ed1745c6.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn24@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-37-59-085_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=sQvyn1T_00o:YC0hKHIW-Zs:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn89@2020_3/2020/09/04/16-38-05-411_ab8cfa5f1c79859b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/sQvyn1T_00o":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn71@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-37-53-614_e592dc3cd4cd82f7.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599237433630},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","title":"There are 614 billionaires in the United States, and only 7 of them are Black","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/black-billionaires-in-the-united-states-2020-2","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e4196183b62b7065e5c28d6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"oprah\" height=\"1997\" width=\"2662\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Oprah Winfrey made a multimillion-dollar fortune from her media empire.\n<p class=\"copyright\">REUTERS/Lucy Nicholson</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Only seven of the United States' 615 billionaires are Black, <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/billionaires/#391dcbae251c\">Forbes' Billionaires List</a> shows.</li>\n<li>All seven of the billionaires on this list are self-made, although their sources of wealth range from finance to technology to entertainment.</li>\n<li>The lack of diversity in the three comma club highlights the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/united-states-racial-wealth-gap-cost-economy-2019-8\">growing wealth gap</a> between Black and white Americans.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>It's not easy for anyone to become a billionaire in America, but it's likely even harder if you're Black.</p><p>Only seven of the United States' 614 billionaires are African American, <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/billionaires/#391dcbae251c\">Forbes' Billionaires List</a> shows. The staggeringly low number of American billionaires that identify as being of African descent highlights the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/united-states-racial-wealth-gap-cost-economy-2019-8\">widening chasm</a> between the economic opportunities afforded to Black and white Americans.</p><p>In 1992, the median net worth of white families was $100,000 above that of Black families, according to <a href=\"https://www.mckinsey.com/industries/public-sector/our-insights/the-economic-impact-of-closing-the-racial-wealth-gap\">McKinsey</a>. By 2016, the median white family was $152,000 wealthier than its Black counterpart. During that period, the median wealth of white families grew over $50,000, <a href=\"https://www.mckinsey.com/industries/public-sector/our-insights/the-economic-impact-of-closing-the-racial-wealth-gap\">McKinsey</a> reports, but the median wealth of Black families did not grow at all in real terms.</p><p>The United States is facing a national reckoning over racism, as cities across the country&#160;<a href=\"https://www.insider.com/george-floyd-death-15-powerful-images-of-nationwide-protests-2020-5\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\">erupted in protests</a> over the past few weeks following the <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/george-floyd-non-responsive-before-officer-took-knee-off-neck-2020-5\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\">deaths of George Floyd</a>,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.insider.com/ahmaud-arbery-shooting-killed-jogging-travis-gregory-mcmichael-georgia-justice-2020-5\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\">Ahmaud Arbery</a>, and&#160;<a href=\"https://www.insider.com/breonna-taylor-shot-dead-louisville-house-police-narcotics-bust-2020-5\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\">Breonna Taylor</a>.</p><p>However, the diversity problem among the world's wealthiest people isn't just an American one. Only 13 of the 2,153 people on <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/mfonobongnsehe/2019/03/05/the-black-billionaires-2019/#2b8723756795\">Forbes' 2019 Billionaires List</a> were black, the magazine reported. In 2018, that number was 11. Forbes didn't publish a racial breakdown of its <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/billionaires/\">2020 Billionaires List</a>.&#160;</p><p>Keep reading to learn more about America's Black billionaires, listed in ascending order of net worth.</p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tT6. Tyler Perry is America's newest Black billionaire.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4fabb27ed0ee001e25cf74?format=jpeg\" alt=\"tyler perry billionaire\" height=\"1664\" width=\"2225\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Tyler Perry is America&#39;s newest billionaire, according to Forbes.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Axelle/Bauer-Griffin/FilmMagic</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Net worth</strong>: <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/maddieberg/2020/09/01/from-poor-as-hell-to-billionaire-how-tyler-perry-changed-show-business-forever/#e4826d234b51\">$1 billion</a></p><p><strong>Source of wealth</strong>: film and television</p><p>Tyler Perry is an Atlanta-based writer, producer, and actor behind comic productions that tell the often-overlooked stories of Black America on national stage tours, BET, and the silver screen. He's perhaps best known for the 11 Madea films, based on the character of a tough elderly woman he created and portrayed.</p><p>Forbes estimates that Perry has a net worth of&#160;<a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/maddieberg/2020/09/01/from-poor-as-hell-to-billionaire-how-tyler-perry-changed-show-business-forever\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\" data-uri=\"3fc8240da4df1366c74c53430ddcfb36\">$1 billion</a>. Because Perry controls every aspect of his projects' production from his 330-acre Tyler Perry Studios in Atlanta, he generated $1.4 billion in pretax income since 2005,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/maddieberg/2020/09/01/from-poor-as-hell-to-billionaire-how-tyler-perry-changed-show-business-forever\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\" data-uri=\"3fc8240da4df1366c74c53430ddcfb36\">Forbes</a>&#160;reported. Perry told&#160;<a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/maddieberg/2020/09/01/from-poor-as-hell-to-billionaire-how-tyler-perry-changed-show-business-forever\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\" data-uri=\"3fc8240da4df1366c74c53430ddcfb36\">Forbes</a> he adopted that business strategy on the advice of fellow Black billionaire Oprah Winfrey.</p>\n\tT6. Jay-Z grew the proceeds from his music career into a billion-dollar fortune with smart investments.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e3b33270ce3d15c650b3ced?format=jpeg\" alt=\"jay-z\" height=\"1503\" width=\"2004\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Jay-Z.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Paul A. Hebert/AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Net worth</strong>: <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/profile/jay-z/#46e4cbac59cf\">$1 billion</a></p><p><strong>Source of wealth</strong>: music, investments</p><p>Shawn Carter, better known as Jay-Z, may be hip hop's first billionaire, but he didn't make his fortune off his music career alone. Carter pocketed approximately $500 million from his 14 No. 1 albums before taxes, but a large portion of his wealth comes from his business ventures, according to <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/zackomalleygreenburg/2019/06/03/jay-z-billionaire-worth/#482cc3473a5f\">Forbes</a>. He founded a clothing line that he sold to&#160;Iconix for&#160;$204 million in 2007 and co-owns cognac brand D'Uss&#233;,&#160;in addition to owning music streaming service Tidal.</p><p>Jay-Z, 50, bought Tidal for <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/why-sprint-could-think-tidal-is-worth-600-million-2017-1\">$56 million in 2015</a>. In 2017,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/why-sprint-could-think-tidal-is-worth-600-million-2017-1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Sprint bought a 33% stake</a> in the company for $200 million, which put the company's valuation at $600 million. Jay-Z's stake in the company is worth $100 million, <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/zackomalleygreenburg/2019/06/03/jay-z-billionaire-worth/#4da996383a5f\">Forbes</a> reported in 2019.</p><p>Jay-Z also has a private art collection worth $70 million, a stake in Uber worth $70 million, and he owns $50 million in real estate, according to <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/zackomalleygreenburg/2019/06/03/jay-z-billionaire-worth/#4da996383a5f\">Forbes</a>.</p>\n\t5. Kanye West may be best known as a musician, but he owes his membership in the three comma club to his streetwear line.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5db34908dee0190573163c97?format=jpeg\" alt=\"kanye west\" height=\"2003\" width=\"2671\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Kanye West.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Net worth</strong>: <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/is-kanye-west-finally-a-billionaire-forbes-says-yes-2020-4\">$1.3 billion</a></p><p><strong>Source of wealth</strong>: music, streetwear brand Yeezy</p><p>After a years-long campaign by West to get added to the magazine's annual Billionaires List, Forbes <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/is-kanye-west-finally-a-billionaire-forbes-says-yes-2020-4\">declared</a> Kanye West a billionaire in April. <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/zackomalleygreenburg/2020/04/24/kanye-west-is-now-officially-a-billionaireand-he-really-wants-the-world-to-know/#95df2e87b9ec\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\">Forbes</a> now says that the 43-year-old rapper and fashion designer is worth $1.3 billion, mostly because of his sole ownership of his brand Yeezy. West reportedly <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/zackomalleygreenburg/2020/04/24/kanye-west-is-now-officially-a-billionaireand-he-really-wants-the-world-to-know/#1df210a37b9e\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\">claims that he is worth $3.3 billion</a>.</p>\n\t4. Michael Jordan used his success as a basketball player to build a best-selling footwear brand.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e3b2b5c0ce3d150f81e9703?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Michael Jordan\" height=\"2610\" width=\"3480\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Former basketball superstar Michael Jordan speaks during a press conference ahead of NBA basketball game between Charlotte Hornets and Milwaukee Bucks in Paris, Friday, Jan. 24, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\">AP Photo/Thibault Camus</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Net worth</strong>: <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/profile/michael-jordan/#137d37b62d83\">$1.6 billion</a></p><p><strong>Source of wealth</strong>: sports, endorsements</p><p>Jordan, 57, is the highest-paid athlete of all time, but not because of his salary from the Chicago Bulls. Jordan earned <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/kurtbadenhausen/2018/03/28/michael-jordan-adds-350-million-to-fortune-net-worth-now-1-65-billion/#1b13b6e72848\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">$1.4 billion</a>&#160;before taxes from corporate sponsorships during his professional basketball career. His film debut, \"Space Jam,\" also earned $250 million at the worldwide box office, according to&#160;<a href=\"https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0117705/\">IMDB</a>.&#160;</p><p>He went on to purchase an NBA team, the Charlotte Hornets, in 2010. The Hornets may be the third least-valuable NBA franchise according to <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/kurtbadenhausen/2018/03/28/michael-jordan-adds-350-million-to-fortune-net-worth-now-1-65-billion/#369597fe2848\">Forbes</a>, but the team's valuation at $1.05 billion is still a major part of Jordan's wealth. Jordan has also made a lot of money from Nike's Air Jordan line, which made him a billionaire in 2015, according to&#160;<a href=\"https://money.cnn.com/2015/03/02/news/michael-jordan-billionaire-list/index.html\">CNN Business</a>.</p>\n\t3. Oprah Winfrey made a multimillion-dollar fortune from her media empire.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dc2fe6f7eece563811ec5eb?format=jpeg\" alt=\"FILE - In this Nov. 29, 2018 file photo, Oprah Winfrey smiles during a tribute to Nelson Mandela and promoting gender equality event at University of Johannesburg in Soweto, South Africa.  Winfrey surprised the Maui Humane Society with a visit to thank the organization for evacuating animals during a wildfire. The Maui News reported Saturday, July 13, 2019, that Winfrey is a part-time Maui resident who only visited briefly Saturday, thanking a volunteer and taking a photo outside with the organization’s sign. A Maui Humane Society official says Winfrey is a society supporter.  (AP Photo/Themba Hadebe, File)\" height=\"2968\" width=\"3957\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Oprah Winfrey smiles during a tribute to Nelson Mandela in November 2019.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Themba Hadebe/AP Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Net worth</strong>: <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/profile/oprah-winfrey/#661d6425745f\">$2.5 billion</a></p><p><strong>Source of wealth</strong>: media</p><p>Born to a single mother in rural Mississippi, Winfrey started out as a news anchor before spending 25 years hosting \"The Oprah Winfrey Show.\" The investments Winfrey made with her share of the show's profits are now worth about $2 billion,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/profile/oprah-winfrey/?list=billionaires#4d25a16b5745\">Forbes</a>&#160;estimates. She became a billionaire in 2003, according to&#160;<a href=\"https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-2003-feb-28-fi-rup28.3-story.html\">the Los Angeles Times</a>.&#160;</p><p>Winfrey, now 66, also leveraged her show's success to build a media empire and amassed a fortune of $2.6 billion in the process, according to <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/profile/oprah-winfrey/?list=billionaires#4d25a16b5745\">Forbes</a>. She owns 25.5% of her television network OWN, an 8% stake in WW International, and has a content creation deal with Apple TV+.</p><p>Oprah has also voiced characters in \"Charlotte's Web,\" \"The Bee Movie,\" and \"The Princess and the Frog,\" in addition to starring in \"Lee Daniels' The Butler\" and \"Selma,\" among others, according to&#160;<a href=\"https://www.oprahmag.com/entertainment/tv-movies/g25777276/oprah-movies-list/\">The Oprah Magazine</a>.</p>\n\t2. David Steward built his fortune running an IT service provider that counts Citi, Verizon, and the federal government as clients.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e3b33ffd9db1d5c2c600639?format=jpeg\" alt=\"david steward\" height=\"3648\" width=\"4864\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>David Steward speaks during the dedication of a new community empowerment center in Ferguson, Missouri in 2017.\n<p class=\"copyright\">AP Photo/Jeff Roberson</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Net worth</strong>: <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/profile/david-steward/?list=billionaires/#65823c705626\">$3.7 billion</a></p><p><strong>Source of wealth</strong>: information technology services</p><p>Steward founded World Wide Technology, an IT services company that has generated over $11 billion in sales, according to <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/profile/david-steward/?list=billionaires/#43fd3f945626\">Forbes</a>. Steward, 68, serves as the company's chairman. The Missouri-based billionaire still has a majority stake in the company.</p>\n\t1. Investor Robert F. Smith is the richest black man in the country.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ed5168af0f41970af1a5219?format=jpeg\" alt=\"robert f smith memo\" height=\"1785\" width=\"2380\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Robert F. Smith.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Kevin Mazur / Contributor / Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Net worth</strong>: <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/profile/robert-smith/#110b9e9e61df\">$5.2 billion</a></p><p><strong>Source of wealth</strong>: private equity</p><p>A Cornell graduate and former Goldman Sachs executive, Smith built his multibillion-dollar fortune running private equity firm Vista Equity Partners, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ex-goldman-sachs-tech-dealmaker-robert-smith-american\">Business Insider</a> previously reported. Vista is one of the most successful private equity firms in the nation, with more than $46 billion in assets and posting <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/profile/robert-f-smith/#6ce956aa2236\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">annualized returns of 22%</a>.</p><p>Smith became the first African American to sign <a href=\"https://givingpledge.org/Pledger.aspx?id=340\">The Giving Pledge</a> in 2017, an invitation-only alliance of billionaires who have pledged to give away the majority of their fortunes. Smith is perhaps best known for his philanthropy. In May 2019, he announced a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/robert-f-smith-morehouse-grads-parents-student-debt-pledge-2019-9\">$34 million gift</a> to pay off the student loans of Morehouse College's class of 2019 while speaking during the historically black college's graduation ceremony. Smith later <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/robert-f-smith-morehouse-grads-parents-student-debt-pledge-2019-9\">expanded the gift</a> to cover the graduates' parents' educational debt.</p>\n</div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/black-billionaires-in-the-united-states-2020-2'>Business Insider</a></div><div +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f4fabb27ed0ee001e25cf74?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"416a7d6c695cd1c51f1ec8c4fde9be9c","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn19@2020_2/2020/09/04/16-37-13-834_b7efa8866ee424a0.webp","destWidth":2225,"destHeight":1664,"sourceBytes":143148,"destBytes":143148,"author":"trogers@businessinsider.com (Taylor Nicole Rogers)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5e4196183b62b7065e5c28d6?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn76@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-37-58-695_5f049aaa07b2412f.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f4fabb27ed0ee001e25cf74?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn19@2020_2/2020/09/04/16-37-13-834_b7efa8866ee424a0.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e3b33270ce3d15c650b3ced?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn4@2020_3/2020/09/04/16-37-54-443_89920d4663e02b7e.webp","https://i.insider.com/5db34908dee0190573163c97?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn79@2020_4/2020/09/04/16-37-55-580_f255fb37b8686cdd.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e3b2b5c0ce3d150f81e9703?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn11@2020_5/2020/09/04/16-37-55-019_74bebb6ca476154d.webp","https://i.insider.com/5dc2fe6f7eece563811ec5eb?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn60@2020_2/2020/09/04/16-38-02-127_835334edd7e1ac26.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e3b33ffd9db1d5c2c600639?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn31@2020_3/2020/09/04/16-38-01-085_3049c1380f3a9ad2.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ed5168af0f41970af1a5219?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn91@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-38-03-736_da35914d18dda671.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn3@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-38-03-978_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=VugJEmHlEOk:V9VkxHW2S-M:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn76@2020_3/2020/09/04/16-37-44-666_dcb9f526eb6427fc.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=VugJEmHlEOk:V9VkxHW2S-M:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn87@2020_2/2020/09/04/16-37-55-672_5a683a66a56cba65.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn24@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-37-59-085_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=VugJEmHlEOk:V9VkxHW2S-M:gIN9vFwOqvQ":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/VugJEmHlEOk":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn20@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-37-59-177_60291f1cdb5c6b9d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599237433609},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","title":"'We've now left the part of the recovery where there were lots of easy wins': Here's what 4 economists had to say about the August jobs report","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/august-jobs-report-economists-reaction-commentary-economy-recovery-020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5be543bb1011420a5d128bc2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"now hiring\" height=\"477\" width=\"954\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Tim Boyle/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>In August, the US economy added 1.37 million jobs and the unemployment rate fell to 8.4%, the Labor Department reported Friday.&#160;</li>\n<li>The report narrowly beat economist expectations, showing that the labor market recovery from the coronavirus pandemic is moving forward. Still, economists worry that the pace of recovery has stalled.&#160;</li>\n<li>Here's what four economists had to say about the report.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Even though the August jobs report beat expectations, economists warned that it also showed that the labor market recovery from the coronavirus pandemic recession has stalled, and that there's underlying damage to the US economy that could leave lasting scars.&#160;</p><p>The US economy added back <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/august-jobs-report-nonfarm-payrolls-unemployment-rate-us-economy-recovery-2020-9\">1.37 million jobs in August</a> and the unemployment rate ticked down to 8.4%, beating economist estimates for gains and notching the first single-digit unemployment rate of the pandemic recession. The most jobs were gained in sectors hit hardest by the pandemic, including leisure and hospitality, education and health, and retail.&#160;</p><p>\"This was an impressive report and once again shows the economy remains quite resilient,\" said Ryan Detrick, chief market strategist at LPL Financial, in a note. \"But 8% unemployment is still 8% unemployment, so let's not get too excited.\"</p><p>Economists also noted that there are underlying signs of trouble in the report. Even though the jobs report showed payrolls were added and came in above consensus, it's less than the 1.8 million jobs added in the previous month. And jobs added back in top sectors were also far fewer than in previous reports.&#160;</p><p>This signals that the pace of the labor market recovery is still slowing from the record gains seen in May and June. The more the recovery slows, the longer it will take to recoup the 11.5 million jobs needed to reach pre-pandemic February levels.&#160;</p><p>Here's what else four economists had to say about the August jobs report.&#160;</p><p><strong>1. Navy Federal Credit Union: \"The easier jobs gains are over\"</strong></p><p>\"The hiring of Census workers significantly added to jobs, but there were other key gains in the hard-hit retailing sector,\" said Robert Frick, corporate economist at Navy Federal Credit Union.</p><p>\"Unfortunately, the easier jobs gains are over, and now we'll be battling permanent layoffs once thought to be temporary, bankruptcies, secondary layoffs and maybe major layoffs in the airline industry,\" he said. \"Expect that starting this month we'll struggle to drop the unemployment rate as much, and possibly see break-even jobs months and even backsliding.\"</p><p><strong>2. Euler Hermes: \"We've had such a tremendous scar in the labor market\"&#160;</strong></p><p>\"Those people who are on furlough dropped by 3 million this month. So, you know, you could argue in some sense that all of the gains where those people going back to work at jobs that were already there,\" Dan North, chief economist for North America at Euler Hermes, told Business Insider.&#160;</p><p>\"It's an awfully good thing to get people off of furlough, but tt doesn't indicate that we're doing it because of economic growth,\" he said.&#160; \"We've had such a tremendous scar in the labor market. It's healing up pretty well, but you can't expect to see organic growth in the labor market after such terrible damage.\"&#160;</p><p><em><strong>Read more</strong>: <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-invest-in-real-estate-after-coronavirus-tips-ubs-2020-9\" data-analytics-position=\"3\" data-analytics-module=\"\">A UBS real estate-investing chief told us 5 ways investors can profit from the pandemic's transformation of how Americans live and work — including the housing markets poised to boom</a></em></p><p><strong>3. Indeed: \"We've now left the part of the recovery where there were lots of easy wins\"</strong></p><p>\"Underneath that top line number, there are some signs that there's more enduring forms of joblessness that are arising,\" Nick Bunker, an economist at Indeed, told Business Insider.</p><p>He added that the pace of jobs added back in the hardest hit sectors, such as retail and leisure and hospitality, have greatly slowed.&#160;</p><p>\"All this evidence suggests to me that the pace of improvement moving forward the next few months, it's likely to slow down and that we've now left the part of the recovery where there were lots of easy wins.\"</p><p><strong>4. ING: \"There are major challenges for the economy\"</strong></p><p>\"With a range of data pointing to a leveling off in activity since July it is likely that unemployment stays persistently high and that the US economy will not fully recoup all its lost output before mid-2022 unless there is a new large fiscal stimulus and good news on a vaccine,\" said James Knightley, chief international economist at ING, in a Friday note.&#160;</p><p>\"Phase one of the recovery certainly went better than we could have hoped as the economy re-opened and a combination of pent up demand and generous unemployment support programs fueled growth,\" he said.&#160;</p><p>\"However, the current environment of weak consumer confidence, employment still being 11.6mn less than February, the hit to incomes from the cut in unemployment payments and the absence of a broader fiscal support package means there are major challenges for the economy as it tries to recoup all its lost output.\"&#160;</p><div +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5be543c6f556fc049b0a8083?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"13089b9a64bbea1d7186bce49c01353e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn12@2020_5/2020/09/04/16-37-34-508_7366b4075f3e3950.webp","destWidth":636,"destHeight":477,"sourceBytes":32642,"destBytes":32642,"author":"insider@insider.com (Carmen Reinicke)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5be543bb1011420a5d128bc2?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn33@2020_5/2020/09/04/16-37-34-140_edd8d331f884d9e6.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn3@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-38-03-978_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=VAzDSgqqvME:Vvu7_oTUbRw:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn59@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-38-00-265_7ba4db31b92e4efa.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=VAzDSgqqvME:Vvu7_oTUbRw:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn56@2020_5/2020/09/04/16-38-04-326_d4736c86ab5ee77c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn24@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-37-59-085_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=VAzDSgqqvME:Vvu7_oTUbRw:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn64@2020_3/2020/09/04/16-38-00-276_e1c7a9cdd4d74346.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/VAzDSgqqvME":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn23@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-38-00-992_4f868fb1f693c965.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599237433616},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","title":"What it takes to become a backup dancer for Beyoncé","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/heres-what-it-takes-to-dance-for-beyonce-backup-dancers-show-choreography-2018-6","description":"<div style=\"position:relative; overflow:hidden; padding-bottom:56.25%\">\n<iframe src=\"https://cdn.jwplayer.com/players/DSKtGIBJ-jZbcmOYf.html\"\nwidth=\"100%\" height=\"100%\" frameborder=\"0\" scrolling=\"auto\" title=\"What it takes to become a backup dancer for Beyoncé\"\nstyle=\"position:absolute;\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n</div><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>JaQuel Knight has been doing choreography for Beyonc&#233; for years.</li>\n<li>Knight landed his breakthrough gig at 18 years old for Beyonc&#233;'s iconic video <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4m1EFMoRFvY\">\"Single Ladies.\"</a></li>\n<li>His most recent collaboration with her at <a href=\"http://www.insider.com/beyonce-reunites-destinys-child-at-coachella-2018-4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Coachella</a>&#160;left people speechless.</li>\n<li>We spoke with Knight about how he got into dancing and what it takes to be her backup dancer.</li>\n</ul>\n<ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p><em>Following is a transcript of the video.</em></p><p><strong>Narrator:</strong> JaQuel Knight is the creative mind behind many of Beyoncé's iconic performances. He's worked with her for years and he's been dancing his entire life.</p><p><strong>Knight:</strong> I remember dancing in my grandmother's living room. And then when I was 16, I started my own dance group with my best friend in Atlanta. So that was kinda the first serious step towards choreography and creative direction.</p><p><strong>Narrator:</strong> At just 18, JaQuel landed a gig choreographing one of the best videos of all time, \"Single Ladies.\" Years later, JaQuel reveals what it takes to be a backup dancer for Beyoncé.</p><p><strong>Knight:</strong> To work for B as a dancer, it takes everything, you know. She's a southern girl, you know, who's worked very hard to get where she is. So she wants people to do the same. She wanna know that you want it really bad. She wanna see your heart, your passion, your drive. And then, you know, you gotta be able to jam. How greasy can you get? How can you hit it hard? Then there's also the side of her that's looking for the technical element. You know, are you trained? Do you have any ballet training? Do you have any jazz training? How are your lines? You know, so there's a few things that go into the process.</p><p>And once we start to audition things, you know, we look for everything. We teach them hip-hop number, we teach them a super difficult technical number, we teach them the classic Beyoncé number, you know. And then besides that, you know, you gotta be able to carry the stage, you know, with her. You gotta be able to stand next to her and be just as good, you know. And sometimes people are ready, sometimes they're not. You can be a great dancer, but it may not come through when you get on stage. You may kind of pull into a shell, don't know who to look at. So she's looking for stars. Star dancers, who have magic. That can bring it, you know, and pull other people in, always.</p><p>Working with B during the rehearsal process is like, it's kind of an out of body experience, ya know. People don't understand the amount of effort her work ethic is out of this world. And it's never just one thing. When we're creating choreography, it's okay, boom. Where's the wardrobe at? You know, bring them in so they can see what the choreography is. Okay boom. Where are we on this stage? You know, let's make sure lighting knows how to light this, boom. Where are the cameras? Okay, let's look at this camera and then do this.</p><p>You know, we're always thinking of every single piece of the puzzle. But you know, at the end of the day, we send her pictures, we send her videos. She's watching people in rehearsal like who's that? Okay, that's so and so that we talked about. She's like okay, she's good. You know, she's looking at everything at every moment, you know. So she's like heavily involved.</p><p><em>EDITOR'S NOTE: This video was originally published in July 2018.</em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/heres-what-it-takes-to-dance-for-beyonce-backup-dancers-show-choreography-2018-6'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=RZ-uXjmT0Kk:NjD-DRx9BWg:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=RZ-uXjmT0Kk:NjD-DRx9BWg:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=RZ-uXjmT0Kk:NjD-DRx9BWg:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=RZ-uXjmT0Kk:NjD-DRx9BWg:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=RZ-uXjmT0Kk:NjD-DRx9BWg:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=RZ-uXjmT0Kk:NjD-DRx9BWg:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=RZ-uXjmT0Kk:NjD-DRx9BWg:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=RZ-uXjmT0Kk:NjD-DRx9BWg:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/RZ-uXjmT0Kk\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 14:30:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5b32ae4a1ae66239008b48c3?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"7f62cc1bc24ae17a65123d82627e39de","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn4@2020_3/2020/09/04/16-37-34-360_cb421daf87855be3.webp","destWidth":3770,"destHeight":2827,"sourceBytes":433892,"destBytes":433892,"author":"eocbazghi@businessinsider.com (Emmanuel Ocbazghi)","articleImgCdnMap":{"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn3@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-38-03-978_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=RZ-uXjmT0Kk:NjD-DRx9BWg:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn9@2020_5/2020/09/04/16-38-05-562_0916fa9b9c233d26.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=RZ-uXjmT0Kk:NjD-DRx9BWg:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn8@2020_3/2020/09/04/16-37-50-048_3e366bc5d99766e8.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn24@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-37-59-085_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=RZ-uXjmT0Kk:NjD-DRx9BWg:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn36@2020_3/2020/09/04/16-37-50-832_7eec940a177f362f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/RZ-uXjmT0Kk":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn43@2020_5/2020/09/04/16-37-52-716_f682688d2c0b405a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599237433625},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","title":"The private jet industry is bracing for fall without its biggest money maker: business travelers. Execs are hoping wealthy vacationers can make up the difference.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-private-aviation-execs-are-preparing-for-business-travel-loss-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4947f67ffa48002894ce84?format=jpeg\" alt=\"4x3 private aviation CEOs\" height=\"1500\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Private aviation is at a crossroads following a busy summer for leisure travel and executives are waiting to see if business travel rebounds in the fall.\n<p class=\"copyright\">XOJET; FXAIR; Silver Air; Sylvain Gaboury/Patrick McMullan via Getty Images; Flexjet; Samantha Lee/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Private aviation executives say the industry has succeeded in gaining back most of the business lost to the pandemic but the recovery isn't yet complete.</li>\n<li>Private jet travel bounced back in the summer after some firms booked no flights at all in late March and April with the fall looking similarly promising thanks to a new market of leisure flyers.</li>\n<li>Firms are moving to capture as much of the new market as possible by scaling up, adopting advanced scheduling and pricing systems, and enhancing safety protocols.&#160;</li>\n<li>Business Insider spoke with eight private aviation executives to learn how each is approaching the upcoming seasonal transition.&#160;&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Fall is coming and the private aviation industry's recovery hinges on it being a kind one.</p><p>Private aircraft firms have gone from their worst months of the year to their best, or at least getting close to 2019 levels, following a devastating spring.</p><p>March and April saw even the largest operators experience near-zero traffic with some choosing to ground their fleets entirely.</p><p>\"We went from an average of 136 to 146 hours a day on fleet, to 19 on our lowest day,\" Kevin Thomas, chief operating officer at XOJET Aviation, told Business Insider.</p><p>As months of lockdowns eased by the end of summer, the desire to move around eventually surpassed fear of the virus for some and the wealthy began traveling again. Relying more on private planes, travel plans were shaped around quarantine rules and airlines were largely avoided for those who could afford it.</p><p>A fast rebounding leisure segment over the summer gave firms an early indicator of how the sector's slump earlier in 2020 might be short-lived.</p><p>Now, with new safety protocols in place and a positive industry outlook, private aircraft firms are changing their playbooks. They're moving to capture as many new clients as they can this fall to counter the expected loss of business travel, which typically comes this time of year as summer leisure travel peters out.</p><h2><strong>The road to recovery</strong></h2><p><strong><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f49456e7ffa48002894ce6d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Gulfstream G550\" height=\"1316\" width=\"1755\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>This summer saw a drop in private jet charter traffic by an average of around 20% for July and August.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Andrew Harker/Shutterstock.com</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></strong></p><p>Private aviation saw an active summer with traffic rising so close to last year's levels that executives are expecting a quick return to normal, the opposite of what the mainline airline industry is currently experiencing.</p><p>\"June was our biggest month ever, by far,\" Jason Middleton, chief executive officer of Silver Air, told Business Insider. His company's June had surpassed its year-on-year numbers by nearly 40 percent, with July and August also nearing last year's levels.</p><p>Firms that couldn't meet 2019 numbers were still coming close as Jet Linx CEO Jamie Walker told Business Insider that his company's June was only 15% off from the year prior. Traffic then increased in July and August to 10% down from last year.&#160;</p><p>Walker's experience is closer to the industry average, according to data from the aviation auditor Argus. It showed that year-on-year traffic was only down 19.6% for July and is slated to be down around 20% for August, according to Travis Kuhn, Argus' vice president for market intelligence.</p><p>Health and safety concerns drove the wealthy to book private aircraft for their leisure travel versus flying the airlines, executives say, with a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/flying-private-new-socially-conscious-choice-2020-5\">recent McKinsey &#38; Company study</a> revealing a massive untapped market of non-private flying high-net-worth individuals ripe for firms to capture.&#160;</p><p>As industry leaders are questioning whether business travel will meaningfully return this fall, executives hope the new leisure market will carry them until the holiday travel season. Currently, the outlook for the fall is quite strong.</p><p>September traffic is slated to be down only 16%, dropping to 13% in October, Kuhn predicts, with help from the new flyers.</p><p>\"The increase in private or personal travel that we're seeing is offsetting the vast majority of the business travel that we've seen erode this year,\" Patrick Gallagher, president, sales, marketing, and service at NetJets, told Business Insider, noting that the rise of personal flights \"is like nothing that we've ever experienced before.\"</p><h2><strong>Investing in new planes and pilots</strong></h2><p><strong><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4946997ffa48002894ce79?format=jpeg\" alt=\"XOJET Aviation Cessna Citation X\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Executives are looking towards expansion to help capture the next generation of private flyers.\n<p class=\"copyright\">XOJET Aviation</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></strong></p><p>Some firms are focused on expansion as there's <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/private-jet-firms-buying-new-planes-hiring-pilots-during-downturn-2020-8\">greater availability of planes and experienced former airline pilots</a> that can be used to scale up to take advantage of the new opportunity.</p><p>XOJET Aviation is eyeing 10 to 20 additional planes for its fleet of 40-strong by 2023. All current aircraft are also getting an interior cabin upgrade and new paint jobs.</p><p>\"Our plan is a long-term plan and the opportunity in a soft market is to add to the fleet in a cost-effective and intelligent manner, makes sense for us to do it right now,\" Thomas said.</p><p>In July, Jet Linx acquired Meridian Air Charter and 23 managed aircraft, establishing it as the country's second-largest aircraft management firm. Walker navigated Jet Linx through the 2008 economic recession and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/private-jet-firm-jet-linx-acquires-meridian-ceo-interview-2020-7\">is applying the same guiding principle this time around</a> — expansion.</p><p>Despite a near-90% traffic loss in March and April, Jet Linx doubled sales for jet cards – prepaid commitments where flyers lock in favorable rates – sales this summer with first-timers accounting for 90% of new sales from March to July, Walker said.</p><h2>The rise of the flexible, premium operator</h2><p><strong><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4947687ffa48002894ce80?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Bombardier Global Express\" height=\"1053\" width=\"1404\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Executives believe that traditional on-demand charter will fall prey to flexible, floating fleet operators that use dynamic pricing and have advanced scheduling systems.\n<p class=\"copyright\">FXAIR</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></strong></p><p>The new paradigm shift will require more technologically-savvy operators in order to keep up with fast-changing travel trends, executives predict. Firms that can offer dynamic pricing backed by a large fleet of nomadic aircraft constantly moving around the country will be better off.</p><p>Travelers aren't just going away for the weekend anymore, they're going for entire seasons. Those flyers require one-way flights, something traditional operators cannot typically offer without charging for costly repositioning legs to get aircraft back to home base.</p><p>\"The leisure flying that we have this summer is not the normal leisure flying that we had last summer,\" Ronald Silverman, chief business officer of XOJET Aviation's sister company, XO, told Business Insider. \"And while the numbers exceed last summer, it's a new kind of passenger, it's a new kind of flying.\"</p><p>The floating fleet model relies on advanced scheduling and pricing technology to maximize efficiency. It also benefits business travelers who may not want to stay overnight when traveling since multiple aircraft can be used on the outbound and return legs, eliminating flight crew duty day concerns.</p><p>Directional Aviation is also aiming to combine that technology with a premium charter offering, called FXAIR. The organization's new on-demand charter wing will use second-hand Flexjet aircraft to provide key tenets that its leadership says is missing from the current charter experience – \"safety, stability, and consistency.\"</p><p>\"In us launching FXAIR, we have changed the narrative from charter to what we call premium charter,\" Gregg Slow, FXAIR's president, told Business Insider.&#160;</p><p>Directional Aviation initially wanted to launch FXAIR later in 2020 or 2021 but the new market opportunity couldn't be passed up, according to FXAIR's leaders. Its fleet of Nextant 400XT, Challenger 300, and Global Express aircraft will float around the country, utilizing similar scheduling and pricing technology to connect aircraft with passengers.</p><p>\"You're going to see dynamic pricing attributes that are going to be really important and the technology that drives them,\" FXAIR CEO Andrew Collins told Business Insider, noting that \"smart routing\" will be equally important to effectively drive revenue.&#160;</p><h2><strong>Changing the sales formula</strong></h2><p><strong><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4947af7ffa48002894ce82?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Private jet COVID-19\" height=\"1665\" width=\"2221\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Private aircraft operators are investing in new safety protocols to sell peace of mind to clients.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Silver Air</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></strong></p><p>The private aviation conversation has moved away from solely the price of the service.</p><p>\"Today, it's more health and safety,\" Michael Silvestro, chief executive officer of Flexjet, told Business Insider. \"No doubt.\"</p><p>When facing a hefty private charter bill, customers want to know that the investment they're making in their health is justified. It's not enough for private aviation to rest on its laurels and the inherent perks of convenience and exclusivity, firms still have to earn new business.</p><p>\"We're seeing a little bit of a flight to quality,\" Gallagher said.&#160;</p><p>The downtime from March to May proved useful for some firms that used it to craft new strategies for bringing in next-generation clients to help lessen the impact of a slow fall for business travel.</p><p>\"We were very bullish going in April and we basically built an entire direct-to-consumer sales team and strategy during our downtime and COVID,\" Middleton said. \"And we came out of it with this amazing sales team and our revenue has ramped up quite a bit.\"</p><p>Silver's strategy aims to cut out aircraft brokers and have clients come directly to them. Education is at the heart of the strategy, extolling the benefits of private charter over flying commercial beyond just the additional material luxuries.</p><h2>Bridging the final gap</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f495f9e60bf1f00280794da?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Gulfstream G550 private jet\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2223\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>It took over a decade for private aviation to get back to normal following the 2008 economic crisis.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Media_works/Shutterstock.com</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Analysts and executives are still uncertain about when the industry will fully recover as it's unclear when business travel will. Following the 2008 economic crisis, it took the industry 11 years to bounce back, Kuhn said.</p><p>Firms are confident that it will come back sooner and are already preparing for that eventuality. Jet Linx, for example, just introduced a new jet card program for business travelers to help ease that all-important segment back into flying.</p><p>Argus is predicting that the industry will remain around 10% shy of normal levels as the pandemic continues, the threat of a recession at the end lingers, and international travel restrictions remain active as all three hinder business travel.</p><p>\"We're not going to gain that last 10% of the industry back until those things settle out,\" Kuhn said.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/how-private-aviation-execs-are-preparing-for-business-travel-loss-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a
