2020 15:58:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f47d236db1ed00029714434?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"ec38282ee9375a9aa70d6cf377a363b5","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn23@2020_3/2020/09/04/16-37-35-485_62c3d77a7a011845.webp","destWidth":2000,"destHeight":1500,"sourceBytes":208360,"destBytes":208360,"author":"tpallini@businessinsider.com (Thomas Pallini)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f4947f67ffa48002894ce84?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn88@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-37-59-244_cd2f93890abf0ce9.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f49456e7ffa48002894ce6d?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn40@2020_5/2020/09/04/16-38-05-019_5ccb58f202d921ff.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f4946997ffa48002894ce79?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn87@2020_2/2020/09/04/16-37-57-289_dbdf75a022f340c9.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f4947687ffa48002894ce80?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn63@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-37-53-228_15449291d9ed5249.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f4947af7ffa48002894ce82?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn3@2020_2/2020/09/04/16-37-59-819_fbb833a1bf3fe802.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f495f9e60bf1f00280794da?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn96@2020_4/2020/09/04/16-38-07-114_a3bfa1302ce6090d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn3@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-38-03-978_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=h_8F_ew0TKs:s5umXZSBMQg:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn23@2020_4/2020/09/04/16-38-07-364_c0dbb7ab011ff0ba.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=h_8F_ew0TKs:s5umXZSBMQg:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn92@2020_2/2020/09/04/16-38-01-258_497fc26998580d1b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn24@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-37-59-085_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=h_8F_ew0TKs:s5umXZSBMQg:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn100@2020_4/2020/09/04/16-37-52-068_5acdfe30104beb1f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/h_8F_ew0TKs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn60@2020_3/2020/09/04/16-38-06-615_d608dcf26a1810f4.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599237433657},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","title":"Mark Zuckerberg says he personally told President Trump that some of his 'rhetoric was problematic'","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/mark-zuckerberg-told-president-trump-his-rhetoric-was-problematic-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5efc87013f73702292702477?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Mark Zuckerberg\" height=\"2000\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Mark Zuckerberg\n<p class=\"copyright\">Drew Angerer/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Mark Zuckerberg said he has personally discussed with President Donald Trump the use of his \"problematic\" rhetoric.</li>\n<li>\"I have had certain discussions with him in the past where I've told him that I thought some of the rhetoric was problematic,\" the Facebook CEO said in an appearance on CBS News.&#160;</li>\n<li>Zuckerberg announced a series of new policies that will be implemented on the social media platform to help safeguard the integrity of the 2020 election.</li>\n<li>\"This will definitely apply to the president,\" he said.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg said on Thursday that he has called out President Donald Trump's use of \"problematic\" rhetoric.&#160;&#160;</p><p>\"I have had certain discussions with him in the past and where I've told him that I thought some of the rhetoric was problematic,\" Zuckerberg said in <a href=\"https://www.cbsnews.com/news/facebook-zuckerberg-2020-election-misinformation-president-trump/\">an interview</a> with CBS News.</p><p>But the pair have not spoken about the president's more recent social media posts in which he undermined mail-in voting amid the coronavirus pandemic, claiming that it is rife with fraud.&#160;</p><p>\"If I did talk to him, you know, be clear about how — just the importance of making sure that people have confidence in the election,\" Zuckerberg told CBS. \"I certainly think that anyone who's saying that the election is going to be fraudulent, I think that that's problematic. And I think additional context needs to be added to that.\"&#160;</p><div class=\"insider-raw-embed\"><iframe src=\"https://www.facebook.com/plugins/post.php?href=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2FDonaldTrump%2Fposts%2F10164748538560725&show_text=true&width=552&height=263&appId\" width=\"552\" height=\"263\" style=\"border:none;overflow:hidden\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" allowtransparency=\"true\" allow=\"encrypted-media\"></iframe></div><p>Zuckerberg announced sweeping new policies on Thursday that will go into effect on Facebook ahead of Nov. 3 to help safeguard the election process. After the 2016 election, the social media behemoth faced backlash for not taking enough steps to stop foreign entities from using Facebook to spread misinformation among voters. Some critics even deemed the site a threat to democracy.</p><p>This year, Zuckerberg struck a decidedly different tone, <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/zuck/posts/10112270823363411\">writing on Facebook</a>:&#160;\"This election is not going to be business as usual. We all have a responsibility to protect our democracy. I believe our democracy is strong enough to withstand this challenge and deliver a free and fair election.\"</p><p>To this end, Facebook is employing a number of measures, including removing false claims about voting, adding \"authoritative information\" on how to vote, blocking foreign operatives attempts to interfere, and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-ban-political-ads-week-2020-election-2020-9\">freezing new political ads</a> in the week leading up to Election Day.</p><p>\"This will definitely apply to the president,\" Zuckerberg told CBS News. \"Once this policy goes into place, and it will apply to everyone equally.\"</p><div class=\"insider-raw-embed\"><iframe src=\"https://www.facebook.com/plugins/post.php?href=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2FDonaldTrump%2Fposts%2F10164935809995725&show_text=true&width=552&height=187&appId\" width=\"552\" height=\"187\" style=\"border:none;overflow:hidden\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" allowtransparency=\"true\" allow=\"encrypted-media\"></iframe></div><p>Shortly after the announcement, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-campaign-pushes-back-on-new-facebook-election-policies-2020-9\">the Trump campaign accused Zuckerberg of trying to muzzle the president</a>.</p><p>\"In the last seven days of the most important election in our history, President Trump will be banned from defending himself on the largest platform in America,\" Samantha Zager, the Trump campaign's deputy national press secretary, said. \"When millions of voters will be making their decisions, the President will be silenced by the Silicon Valley Mafia, who will at the same time allow corporate media to run their biased ads to swing voters in key states.\"</p><ul class=\"read-more-links\"><li>Read more:</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/twitter-flags-trump-tweets-encouraging-people-to-vote-twice-2020-9\" data-analytics-position=\"4\" data-analytics-module=\"\">Twitter flags Trump's tweets encouraging people to vote twice for 'violating our Civic Integrity Policy'</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-campaign-pushes-back-on-new-facebook-election-policies-2020-9\">Trump campaign pushes back on Facebook's new election policies: 'The President will be silenced by the Silicon Valley Mafia'</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-ban-political-ads-week-2020-election-2020-9\">Facebook will ban new political ads a week before the election</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-will-pay-users-to-quit-app-instagram-election-study-2020-9\">Facebook will pay tens of thousands of users to quit the app ahead of the election so it can study the platform's impact on politics</a></li></ul><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 2020 15:11:24 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f5243557ed0ee001e25d7a4?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"980fbd7943e8f92d37d7a530d237034b","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn43@2020_3/2020/09/04/16-37-47-854_1144d90274b5a5e1.webp","destWidth":2664,"destHeight":1998,"sourceBytes":192454,"destBytes":192454,"author":"oseddiq@insider.com (Oma Seddiq)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5efc87013f73702292702477?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn75@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-38-02-847_c70ee287d13a3395.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn3@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-38-03-978_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=B5nI1Y-CupQ:tbf6dsRaZKY:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn24@2020_5/2020/09/04/16-37-37-078_b973a1ff691f8fe5.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=B5nI1Y-CupQ:tbf6dsRaZKY:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn53@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-38-05-059_1d25b1f08d9fcefc.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn24@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-37-59-085_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=B5nI1Y-CupQ:tbf6dsRaZKY:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn64@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-37-53-359_b7fe2b540f8dfe13.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/B5nI1Y-CupQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn28@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-37-53-455_716162d5f5715c45.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599237433610},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","title":"Only 2 of Facebook's earliest employees stayed at the company — here's what Facebook's first 20 employees are up to now","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/first-20-facebook-employees-where-are-they-working-now-2017","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e5ed0f4fee23d7d821a5db3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Mark Zuckerberg 2007\" height=\"2284\" width=\"3045\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg in 2007.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Paul Sakuma/AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li>Facebook launched in February 2004, and it's come a long way in the last 16 years.&#160;</li><li>Notably, almost all of the company's first 20 employees have since left the company. Only two remain, and you can probably guess who one of them is.&#160;</li><li>Some have become venture capitalists: Kevin Colleran opened Slow Ventures, while Sean Parker worked at Founders Fund for eight years.&#160;</li><li>Others have founded their own companies: Dustin Moskovitz launched Asana, while Steve Chen created YouTube.&#160;</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li></ul><p>Who were the people behind Facebook when it was just a startup? And where are they now?</p><p>Only two of Facebook's first 20 employees still work at the company — and you can probably guess one of them.</p><p>Most left during the social network's early days to work at other tech companies or start their own. Several have become successful investors at large VC firms; many are now absurdly rich following Facebook's IPO in 2012.</p><p>Here's where Facebook's first 20 employees are now.</p><p><em>Alex Heath contributed to an earlier version of this article.</em></p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tDustin Moskovitz, Facebook's first CTO, was Mark Zuckerberg's roommate. The two dropped out of Harvard together to move to California and work on Facebook.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e5d8265fee23d0f6d4a6414?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Dustin Moskovitz\" height=\"1795\" width=\"2393\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Horacio Villalobos - Corbis/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Employed by Facebook:</strong> February 2004 to November 2009</p><p><strong>Position:</strong> Cofounder</p><p><strong><strong>Where he is now: </strong></strong>Moskovitz is the cofounder and CEO at enterprise software company Asana. He also cofounded <a href=\"http://www.goodventures.org/\">Good Ventures</a>, a philanthropic firm with a mission \"to help humanity thrive.\" He has a net worth of nearly $11.6 billion, <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/profile/dustin-moskovitz/#d41f2ca1dd34\">according to Forbes</a>.</p>\n\tChris Hughes cofounded Facebook and served as the site's first spokesman. He later coordinated all social networking aspects of Obama's 2008 campaign.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e5d82dcfee23d101a46c6f3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"chris hughes 2010\" height=\"3331\" width=\"4441\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Facebook cofounder Chris Hughes.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Ramin Talaie/Corbis via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Employed by Facebook:</strong> February 2004 to 2007</p><p><strong>Position at Facebook:</strong> Cofounder</p><p><strong>Where he is now: </strong>After working on Obama's 2008 campaign, Hughes became executive director of Jumo, a startup that tried to utilize social media to change the world. In 2012, he purchased a majority stake in The New Republic and became its executive chairman and editor-in-chief. He <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/12/business/media/chris-hughes-selling-the-new-republic.html\">put the magazine up for sale</a> in 2016 after it failed to become profitable.</p><p>Hughes made $500 million when Facebook went public. He recently wrote a book called \"The Fair Shot: Rethinking Inequality and How We Earn,\" citing his own wealth, most of which stemmed from his 2% ownership in Facebook. And in May 2019, Hughes dropped a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-cofounder-chris-hughes-says-firm-should-be-broken-up-2019-5\">bombshell by publishing an op-ed in The New York Times</a> that called regulators to break up Facebook in order to protect users and competition.&#160;</p><p>Hughes is now co-chair of the <a href=\"https://www.economicsecurityproject.org/team/\">Economic Security Project</a>, a group that wants to make universal basic income a reality in the US.</p>\n\tEduardo Saverin was a Facebook cofounder and its first CFO. He famously sued Mark Zuckerberg and the two reached a settlement.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5914e59a1442934d088b4951?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Eduardo Saverin speaks at the Tech in Asia Singapore 2016\" height=\"908\" width=\"1300\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Edgar Su/Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Employed by Facebook:</strong> February 2004 to 2005</p><p><strong>Position:</strong> Cofounder</p><p><strong>Where he is now:</strong> After winning a legal battle with Facebook that let him retain his cofounder status, Saverin began angel investing in startups like Qwiki and Chris Hughes' Jumo. In 2011, Saverin <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/alexkonrad/2019/03/19/life-after-facebook--the-untold-story-of-billionaire-eduardo-saverins-highly-networked-venture-firm/#604d1af2c8cd\">renounced his US citizenship</a> and moved to Singapore, meaning the taxes he had to pay on capital gains when Facebook went public were significantly reduced.</p><p>He says he has <a href=\"http://www.forbes.com/sites/andersonantunes/2012/05/27/eduardo-saverin-finally-opens-up-no-hard-feelings-between-me-and-mark-zuckerberg/\">no hard feelings</a> when it comes to Facebook or Mark Zuckerberg, who ousted him from the company shortly after its launch. Saverin has a net worth of roughly $10.5 billion, <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/profile/eduardo-saverin/#6cf7d0b17bd5\">according to Forbes</a>.</p>\n\tSean Parker was a cofounder of Napster and was founding president of Facebook.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/593f01aebf76bbde138b5455?format=jpeg\" alt=\"sean parker\" height=\"3243\" width=\"4324\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">AP Photo/Paul Sakuma</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Employed by Facebook:</strong> June 2004 to January 2006</p><p><strong>Position:</strong> President</p><p><strong>Where he is now:&#160;</strong>Parker has invested in a number of tech startups, including Spotify and Asana, and was a partner at VC firm Founder's Fund <a href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2014/03/06/sean-parker-leaves-founders-fund/\">until 2014</a>. He has a personal net worth of roughly $2.7 billion, <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/profile/sean-parker/#5eca5fb34b73\">according to Forbes</a>.</p><p>Parker is an active philanthropist, launching multiple foundations <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/to-your-health/wp/2016/04/13/250-million-300-scientists-and-40-labs-sean-parkers-revolutionary-project-to-solve-cancer/\">focused on cancer</a> and <a href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/sean-parker-philanthropy-for-hackers-1435345787\">public health</a>.&#160;</p>\n\tAndrew McCollum designed Facebook's first logo and worked on a side project with Zuckerberg called Wirehog.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e5ecb20fee23d01ea2f1597?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Andrew McCollum\" height=\"740\" width=\"986\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Philo</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Employed by Facebook:</strong> February 2004 to September 2006</p><p><strong>Position:</strong> Cofounder, engineer</p><p><strong>Where he is now:</strong> McCollum <a href=\"http://www.crunchbase.com/person/andrew-mccollum\">joined Flybridge Capital Partners</a> as an entrepreneur in residence in 2011, then became a partner at the VC firm NEA. He's since invested and become involved in other tech startups, such as Quilt and JobSpice, and is currently the CEO of <a href=\"https://try.philo.com/\">streaming service Philo</a>.&#160;</p>\n\tTaner Halicioglu was Facebook's first \"real\" employee outside of the founders. He built out the entire initial hardware infrastructure.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e5ecc88fee23d0bbe273816?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Taner Halicioglu\" height=\"1080\" width=\"1440\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7BaBUcTH-YI\" target=\"_blank\">UC San Diego/YouTube</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Employed by Facebook:</strong> October 2004 to November 2009</p><p><strong>Position:</strong> Senior software/operations engineer</p><p><strong>Where he is now:</strong><strong>&#160;</strong>Halicioglu became the<strong>&#160;</strong>lead reliability engineer of Battle.net at Blizzard Entertainment. Now he is a lecturer at UC San Diego in the school's Computer Science and Engineering department. He <a href=\"https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/california/articles/2017-03-28/early-facebook-employee-donates-75-million-to-ucsd\">recently donated $75 million</a> to the school to create its Halicioglu Data Science Institute.</p>\n\tNaomi Gleit was tasked early on with making sure \"literally everyone in the world was on the site.\" Aside from Mark Zuckerberg, she's the longest-serving employee still at the company.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e5d847dfee23d216a0106c4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Naomi Gleit\" height=\"1799\" width=\"2399\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Rich Fury/Getty Images for Teen Vogue</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Employed by Facebook: </strong>April 2005 &#8211; present<strong><br /></strong></p><p><strong>First position at Facebook: </strong>Marketing Associate<strong><br /></strong></p><p><strong>Her position now:</strong> Gleit is Facebook's vice president of social good and one of Zuckerberg's top lieutenants. She leads all of the company's efforts around safety check, fundraising tools, and similar features.</p>\n\tKevin Colleran lived with Zuckerberg in Facebook's 2004 summer sublet house in Palo Alto. Now he's a VC.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e5d84e6fee23d1d9a4f4867?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Kevin Colleran\" height=\"1667\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">John Tlumacki/The Boston Globe via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Employed by Facebook:</strong> April 2005 to July 2011</p><p><strong>Position at Facebook:</strong> Global partnerships</p><p><strong>Where he is now:</strong> Colleran was one of the last initial employees to leave Facebook. Now, he's managing director at <a href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2019/04/11/slow-ventures-raises-220m-for-two-new-funds/\">VC firm Slow Ventures</a> with Dave Morin and other early Facebook employees.</p>\n\tGilles Mischler built and designed Facebook's IT infrastructure from the ground up.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e5ed19bfee23d08227f7ef5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Facebook office 2012\" height=\"1582\" width=\"2109\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Workers at the Facebook office in Menlo Park in May 2012.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jeff Chiu/AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Employed by Facebook:</strong> June 2005 to May 2010</p><p><strong>Position:</strong> SiteOps engineer</p><p><strong>Where he is now:</strong> After Facebook, Mischler went to game developer Playdom. He was only there for a few weeks when the company was acquired by Disney for more than $700 million. Mischler worked at Dropbox for five years before becoming an engineer at WeWork. These days, he's retired, <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/gillesmischler/\">according to his LinkedIn</a>.&#160;</p>\n\tYou can thank engineer Scott Marlette for being able to visually stalk all of your friends — he created Facebook's first photo application.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e5d8557fee23d1e293717a4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Scott Marlette\" height=\"1801\" width=\"2401\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Steve Jennings/Getty Images For Techfellows</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Employed by Facebook:</strong> June 2005 to January 2010</p><p><strong>Position:</strong> Engineer, product manager</p><p><strong>Where he is now:</strong> Marlette went on to <a href=\"https://www.montana.edu/news/19514/scott-marlette-co-founder-of-goodrx-and-early-facebook-employee-to-visit-msu-feb-3\">cofound medical startup GoodRx</a>. Now, he's a partner at VC firm Slow Ventures with other early Facebook employees.</p>\n\tAaron Sittig was brought on early from Napster by Sean Parker. He created the concept of tagging friends in Facebook pictures and the \"like\" button.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e5d85b1fee23d1e7a6f3440?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Aaron Sittig Facebook\" height=\"1310\" width=\"1747\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Kimberly White/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Employed by Facebook:</strong> May 2005 to December 2o10, January 2011 to December 2012</p><p><strong>Position:</strong> Design strategy lead, product architect</p><p><strong>Where he is now: </strong>Sittig was Facebook's first designer and a close friend of Mark Zuckerberg. He left the company in 2010 and returned in 2011 for <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/aaronsittig/\">a two-year stint</a> as a product architect. In 2015, he became managing partner at Public Studio, a branding and design studio in San Francisco.</p>\n\tNick Heyman was in charge of handling Facebook's explosive traffic, although he wasn't there for very long.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e5ed200fee23d7ea228fad4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Facebook office 2012\" height=\"1571\" width=\"2095\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A worker in the Facebook office in Menlo Park in 2012.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jeff Chiu/AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Employed by Facebook:</strong> April 2005&#160;</p><p><strong>Position:</strong> Director of operations</p><p><strong>Where he is now:</strong> Heyman has worked at a few other tech companies, including Twitter. He's also invested in startups such as Nuzzel and ShopPad. These days, he's <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/nicolasheyman/\">a managing partner at DynoVC</a>.&#160;</p>\n\tSteve King directed Facebook's media sales and was responsible for getting its first big advertisers, like Panasonic and Microsoft, on board.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e5ed30afee23d12b47c5e7c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Facebook office\" height=\"1250\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Facebook office in New York in 2011.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Eduardo Munoz/Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Employed by Facebook:</strong> April 2005 to July 2006</p><p><strong>Position at Facebook:</strong> Director, media sales</p><p><strong>Where he is now:</strong> After Facebook, King joined LocaModa as its VP of Sales. Now he leads <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/swkmedia/\">a boutique real estate investment firm</a> in the Boston area.</p>\n\tTricia Black worked at Y2M, a firm that sold ads for college magazines. Facebook cofounder Eduardo Saverin set up a meeting with Black, who began selling ads for Facebook and eventually became its first VP of sales.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e5ed347fee23d0a567e1989?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Facebook office\" height=\"1797\" width=\"2396\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Facebook office in New York in 2011.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Eduardo Munoz/Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Employed by Facebook:</strong> March 2005 to June 2006</p><p><strong>Position at Facebook:</strong> Vice president of advertising sales</p><p><strong>What she's doing now:</strong> Black is the founder of <a href=\"https://www.amplifyherventures.com/\">AmplifyHer Ventures</a>, a VC firm that invests in female founders and diverse teams.</p>\n\tSteve Chen left Facebook after a few short months to help start YouTube.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e5d8750fee23d20eb3a1305?format=jpeg\" alt=\"steven chen\" height=\"2292\" width=\"3056\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Steve Chen.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mark Lennihan/AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Employed by Facebook:</strong> For a few months in 2005</p><p><strong>Position at Facebook:</strong> Senior software engineer</p><p><strong>Where he is now:</strong> Chen went on to cofound YouTube, which he <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/09/business/09cnd-deal.html\">sold to Google for $1.65 billion</a>. He cofounded another company, AVOS, in 2011. He now advises Google's investment arm, GV.</p>\n\tMatt Cohler was brought on by early Facebook investor Peter Thiel and was formerly one of the founding members of LinkedIn. Now, he's a partner at VC firm Benchmark Capital.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e5d87aafee23d2167066ae3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Matt Cohler\" height=\"1654\" width=\"2205\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Beck Diefenbach/Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Employed by Facebook:</strong> February 2005 to October 2008</p><p><strong>Position at Facebook:</strong> Vice president of product management</p><p><strong>Where he is now:</strong> Cohler is a general partner at Benchmark Capital and serves on a number of startup boards, including Tinder and Asana. He briefly sat on Uber's board after taking over Bill Gurley's seat in 2017, but <a href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2019/07/24/uber-loses-arianna-huffington-and-benchmarks-matt-cohler-as-board-members/\">has since resigned</a>.</p>\n\tEzra Callahan was roommates with Sean Parker and was hired to \"whittle away\" at Eduardo Saverin's CFO responsibilities.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e5ed3a6fee23d0b364d2fb5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Facebook office\" height=\"1581\" width=\"2108\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Facebook office in New York in 2011.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Eduardo Munoz/Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Employed by Facebook:</strong> December 2004 to July 2010</p><p><strong>Position:</strong> Manager of internal communications, product manager</p><p><strong>Where he is now:</strong> Callahan is <a href=\"https://arriveenterprises.com/ezra-callahan-bio\">cofounder and chief investment office</a> at boutique hotel company Arrive, which has locations in cities across the country, like Palm Springs, Memphis, and Albuquerque.</p>\n\tJames Pereira was Facebook's seventh employee. He left three years later.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e5ed454fee23d155f259048?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Facebook office Mumbai\" height=\"1802\" width=\"2403\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A worker at Facebook&#39;s office in Mumbai, India, in 2016.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Shailesh Andrade/Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Employed by Facebook:</strong> July 2004 to August 2007</p><p><strong>Position:</strong> Engineer</p><p><strong>Where he is now:</strong> He's a software engineer at Boy Gorilla Enterprises in Portland, Oregon, <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/jamesmpereiraii\">according to his Facebook profile</a>.</p>\n\tDaniel Neff had a short, five-month stint as Facebook's 20th employee and was responsible for rolling out new site features.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e5ed25efee23d7f0323b159?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Facebook office 2012\" height=\"1250\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Workers in the Facebook offices in Menlo Park in 2012.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jeff Chiu/AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Employed by Facebook:</strong> May 2005 to October 2005</p><p><strong>Position at Facebook:</strong> Build/release engineer</p><p><strong>Where he is now:</strong> Neff has been at Adobe for 11 years, <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/daniel-neff-61074b/\">according to his LinkedIn profile</a>. He's currently an operations architect at the company.&#160;</p>\n\tMark Zuckerberg founded Facebook. The blue design of the site is partially because of his red-green color blindness.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e5d888dfee23d225c45bfe3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"mark zuckerberg\" height=\"3017\" width=\"4023\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Employed by Facebook:</strong> February 2004 to present</p><p><strong>Position:</strong> CEO and cofounder</p><p><strong>Where he is now: </strong>Still at Facebook, but much, much richer &#8212; <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/profile/mark-zuckerberg/#5785b2243e06\">Forbes</a> pegs his current net worth at $106.8 billion.&#160;</p>\n\tBONUS: Adam D'Angelo was high school friends with Mark Zuckerberg and eventually left Facebook to cofound Quora.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e5ecfe3fee23d0ee552b2b4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Adam D&#39;Angelo Quora\" height=\"1037\" width=\"1382\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">MediaNews Group/Bay Area News via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Employed by Facebook:</strong> November 2006 to June 2008. (Although he technically wasn't one of the first 20 employees, D'Angelo was one of Zuckerberg's best high school friends and <a href=\"http://www.businessinsider.com/what-i-learned-from-being-cto-of-facebook-why-i-started-quora-and-this-is-why-gen-y-kicks-ass-at-entrepreneurship-2010-9\">worked on the social network site long before he was on the payroll</a>.)</p><p><strong>Position at Facebook:</strong> CTO</p><p><strong>Where he is now: </strong>D'Angelo is cofounder and CEO of Quora.</p>\n</div><div fee23d7ea228fad4?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn4@2020_3/2020/09/04/16-38-02-167_9f09897b5348ef91.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e5ed30afee23d12b47c5e7c?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn95@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-37-57-223_0ebf824fe2ea94a3.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e5ed347fee23d0a567e1989?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn80@2020_3/2020/09/04/16-38-06-117_2fff05b50104f673.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e5d8750fee23d20eb3a1305?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn72@2020_2/2020/09/04/16-38-00-340_30a0da46f51889d4.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e5d87aafee23d2167066ae3?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn31@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-38-05-916_19b082e1b738e608.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e5ed3a6fee23d0b364d2fb5?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn47@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-37-55-146_837629b5a96cad45.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e5ed454fee23d155f259048?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_2/2020/09/04/16-38-00-169_9856e442d3549ad6.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e5ed25efee23d7f0323b159?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn67@2020_3/2020/09/04/16-37-58-020_9e790773014370dc.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e5d888dfee23d225c45bfe3?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn96@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-38-02-284_be83f3de15394a4e.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e5ecfe3fee23d0ee552b2b4?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn72@2020_4/2020/09/04/16-37-56-868_83295c0ab195a62a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn3@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-38-03-978_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=QKjzd7Az7Ws:aQvkMScyLDo:F7zBnMyn0Lo":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=QKjzd7Az7Ws:aQvkMScyLDo:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn52@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-37-58-237_b0a50a3a0fe8e4f3.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn24@2020_6/2020/09/04/16-37-59-085_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=QKjzd7Az7Ws:aQvkMScyLDo:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn36@2020_1/2020/09/04/16-38-04-937_46099bf121086bf3.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/QKjzd7Az7Ws":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn28@2020_5/2020/09/04/16-37-51-352_139411d732032b1e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599237433658},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 00:37:13","title":"Major outages at Robinhood and Schwab were spurred by stock splits for Tesla and Apple, report says","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/robinhood-schwab-outages-spurred-tesla-apple-stock-splits-reason-cause-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f52478be6ff30001d4e712b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"NYSE trader worried\" height=\"1249\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Lucas Jackson/Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul><li><strong>The recent stock splits of Apple and Tesla caused major outages at brokerage firms like Robinhood and Charles Schwab on Monday, <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-09-04/robinhood-schwab-outages-triggered-by-apple-tesla-splits?srnd=premium&sref=P6GaGUEIGUEI\">according to Bloomberg.</a></strong></li><li><strong>The stock splits prompted a surged in trading volumes that led to thousands of retail investors being unable to use their brokerage accounts.</strong></li><li><strong>Other popular brokerage firms experienced service disruptions, including TD Ameritrade, Fidelity, and Vanguard.</strong></li><li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestgest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</strong></li></ul><hr><p>Several brokerage firms popular with retail investors <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/robinhood-tdameritrade-schwab-vanguard-stock-trading-site-app-issues-monday-2020-8\">experienced service disruptions on Monday</a> due to the recent stock splits of <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/aapl-stock\">Apple</a> and <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/tsla-stock\">Tesla</a>, <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-09-04/robinhood-schwab-outages-triggered-by-apple-tesla-splits?srnd=premium&sref=P6GaGUEIGUEI\">according to Bloomberg.</a></p><p>Surging trading volumes caused by the stock splits \"contributed to problems\" at Robinhood and <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/tsla-stock\">Charles Schwab</a> on Monday, Bloomberg said, citing people familiar with the matter.</p><p>The disruptions also spread to brokerage firms like TD Ameritrade, Fidelity, and Vanguard.</p><p>Most of the trading issues were solved that day.</p><p>Apple recently completed a 4-for-1 stock split, while Tesla completed a 5-for-1 stock split, both of which went into effect on Monday.</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-sell-off-trades-to-make-warning-signs-ms-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Morgan Stanley's wealth management CIO warns there are 'particularly ominous' signs about the state of the stock market's health — and recommends jumping into these 4 trades during the next major sell-off</a></em></p><p>For Robinhood, the service disruptions included a technical problem that sparked delays to order status updates for customers. It did not face a system-wide outage, according to Bloomberg.</p><p>This isn't Robinhood's first rodeo dealing with glitches and outages. Retail traders were outraged back in March when <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/robinhood-trading-downtime-outage-second-day-backlash-2020-3\">its app was unusable for a period of nearly two days</a> amid a volatile market sell-off.</p><p>For Schwab, a recent change to the storage system it uses to display stock quotes clashed with the heightened trading volumes surrounding Apple and Tesla's split, resulting in an error.</p><p>Meanwhile, TD Ameritrade said issues with its app and website on Monday were \"completely unrelated\" to the stock splits, Bloomberg said.</p><p><strong data-stringify-type=\"bold\"><em data-stringify-type=\"italic\">Read More:&#160;</em></strong><em data-stringify-type=\"italic\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tesla-stock-sale-why-to-buy-retail-investors-tasha-keeney-2020-9?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestgest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" data-stringify-link=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tesla-stock-sale-why-to-buy-retail-investors-tasha-keeney-2020-9\" data-sk=\"tooltip_parent\">One of Tesla's biggest bulls on Wall Street breaks down how the company's $5 billion stock sale could benefit retail investors - and explains why the electric-car giant would still be cheap at $1,400 per share in 2024</a></em></p><div
